questions.text: Anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum are all except:
questions.solution:
• The anterior relations of the third part of the duodenum include the superior mesenteric vessels, the root of the mesentery, and loops of the jejunum.
  • Posterior relations of the third part of the duodenum are the right ureter, right psoas major, right gonadal vessels, the inferior vena cava, and the abdominal aorta (near the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery).
  • Anteriorly, it is related to loops of the jejunum, the root of the mesentery, and the superior mesenteric vessels.
  • It is superiorly related to the head of the pancreas and inferiorly to loops of the jejunum.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 1126.

questions.text:
Arrange the following afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle from medial to lateral:
A. General somatic
B. General visceral
C. Special somatic
D. Special visceral
questions.solution:
From medial to lateral, the afferent columns in the floor of the fourth ventricle are general visceral, special visceral, general somatic, special somatic.

Embryologically, the continuous addition of neuroblasts to the mantle layer of the neural tube produces thickenings ventrally and dorsally – producing the basal and alar plates respectively. A longitudinal groove, called sulcus limitans, marks the boundary between the two.

Basal Plate:
  • Ventral thickening
  • Give rise to motor nucleigeneral visceral efferent nuclei, special visceral efferent of CN IX, X, and XII; and somatic efferent of XII
  • Forms the motor part of the spinal cord (ventral horns)

Alar plate:
  • Dorsal thickenings
  • Give rise to sensory nuclei CN V, VII, VIII, IX, X, inferior olivary nucleus, and mesencephalic nucleus of CNV
  • Forms the sensory part of the spinal cord (dorsal horns).
  • The rhombic lip develops into the cerebellum and its nuclei


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 253.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?
A. Iliococcygeus
B. Pubococcygeus
C. Obturator internus
D. Deep transverse perinei
questions.solution:
lliococcygeus and pubococcygeus are parts of the pelvic diaphragm, which is also known as the levator ani.

The levator ani muscle is a complex unit that consists of 3 muscle components:
  1. Pubococcygeus
  2. Pubovaginalis – elevates the urethra and hence contributes to urinary continence
  3. Puboperinealis – draws the perineal body towards the pubic symphysis
  4. Puboanalis – elevates the anus and keeps the urogenital hiatus narrowed
  5. Puborectalis
  6. Iliococcygeus
 
  • Levator ani muscles are the most important muscles in the pelvic floor and maintain a constant state of contraction.
  • They provide a stable floor and support the weight of the abdominopelvic contents against intra-abdominal forces.
  • Weakening of levatorani and pelvic fascia from stretching or tearing during childbirth, may decrease support for the vagina, bladder, uterus, or rectum or alter the position of the neck of the bladder and urethra.

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 25 .

questions.text: A 25-year-old male came in with an inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joints of his 4th and 5th fingers. He was also unable to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. What is the most likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario, characterized by a positive card test and the inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joints of the 4th and 5th digits, points towards an ulnar nerve injury. The most likely site of injury would be the medial epicondyle (site C).
 
  • An injury at the medial epicondyle affects the ulnar nerve, resulting in paralysis of the flexor carpi ulnaris (causing loss of ulnar deviation) and the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus (causing loss of flexion at the distal interphalangeal joints).
  • This also leads to paralysis and atrophy of the hypothenar muscles, along with sensory loss. However, because the flexor digitorum superficialis (innervated by the median nerve) and the extensor digitorum (innervated by the radial nerve) remain functional, complete paralysis of the 3rd and 4th digits does not occur.
  • The positive card test results from weakness in the palmar interossei, leading to impaired adduction.


Branches and innervation of the ulnar nerve:
- The superficial branch supplies the palmaris brevis and the skin over the palmar surface of the medial one and a half fingers.
- The deep branch travels along the deep palmar arch and innervates all the intrinsic hand muscles, except the first two lumbricals and the thenar muscles.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 784, 785, 859, 860 .

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by Superior Gluteal Nerve?
A. Gluteus Medius
B. Gluteus Minimus
C. Tensor fascia pata
D. Piriformis
questions.solution:
• The gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fascia lata are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve, while the piriformis is innervated by the nerve to the piriformis.
 
  • The superior gluteal nerve arises from the dorsal branches of the L4, L5, and S1 rami and is accompanied by the superior gluteal vessels. It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen, above the piriformis, and divides into superior and inferior branches. This nerve supplies the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae.
 
  • The nerve to the piriformis originates from the dorsal divisions of the S1 and S2 rami.
 
  • The gluteus medius and gluteus minimus function as hip joint abductors and help stabilize the pelvis on the femur during walking. This can be assessed by asking the person to stand on one leg. If the ipsilateral abductors are functioning properly, the pelvis remains level. If the abductors are weak, the pelvis tilts towards the opposite (unsupported) side, resulting in a positive Trendelenburg sign.


 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 1318,1330,1374 .

questions.text:
Match the following:
Column I Column II
1 Facial nerve A Shrugging of shoulder
2 Spinal accessory nerve B Taste from anterior two third of the tongue
3 Glossopharyngeal nerve C Taste from posterior one-third of the tongue
4 Mandibular nerve D Chewing
questions.solution:
1. **Facial nerve** - B. Taste from anterior two-thirds of the tongue
2. **Spinal accessory nerve** - A. Shrugging of shoulder
3. **Glossopharyngeal nerve** - C. Taste from posterior one-third of the tongue
4. **Mandibular nerve** - D. Chewing
Chorda tympani nerve which is a branch of facial nerve carries taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue.

The trapezius is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (CN XI). It causes retraction of scapula, shrugging of the shoulder and overhead abduction (along with serratus anterior). Paralysis of trapezius causes drooping of the shoulder and slight winging of the scapula (the superior angle of scapula becomes more prominent).

The glossopharyngeal nerve carries taste sensation from the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue.

The mandibular nerve (V3) is responsible for chewing movements as it gives motor supply to muscles of mastication. It contains both sensory and motor fibers.

Sensory from
Skin of cheek, over mandible and side of head
Teeth of lower jaw and temporomandibular joint
Mucous membrane of mouth and anterior
Part of tongue

Motor to
E Muscles of mastication (pterygoids, masster and temporalis)
Tensor tympani
Anterior belly of digastric
Mylohyoid
MCQ

questions.text:
Which of the statements given below regarding the muscle shown in the image are correct?



A. They elevate the scapula along with fibres of Trapezius
B. They retract the scapula along with the middle fibres of Trapezius
C. They medially rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly
D. They medially rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly
questions.solution:
• The muscles highlighted in the image are the rhomboids minor and major. These muscles are responsible for retracting and elevating the scapula, as well as rotating it to tilt the glenoid cavity downward.
  • Both the rhomboid minor and major are innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve, and receive blood supply from either the dorsal scapular artery or the deep branch of the transverse cervical artery. 

MUSCLES INVOLVED IN MOVEMENT OF SCAPULA
 
  • ELEVATION - Levator scapulae, Trapezius and Rhomboids. 
  • DEPRESSION - Gravity, if further - Pectoralis Minor/Serratus anterior and Trapezius. 
  • PROTRACTION - P. Minor & Serratus anterior. L. dorsi (upper part) - functions as strap across the inferior angle of scapula during scapular protraction
  • RETRACTION - Middle fibres of Trapezius & Rhomboids

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 818,819 .

questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition affecting the region marked in red in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The image provided is indicative of lateral medullary syndrome, also known as Wallenberg syndrome, which can occur due to a stroke affecting the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

The clinical manifestations correspond to the affected neuroanatomical structures in the lateral medulla:

•Descending tract and nucleus of CN V (trigeminal nerve): Loss of pain and sensation on the ipsilateral side of the face.

•Inferior cerebellar peduncle:Ipsilateral ataxia affecting gait and limbs.


•Lateral spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain and temperature sensation on the contralateral side of the body.

•Cranial nerves IX and X: Ipsilateral paralysis of the palate and vocal cord, along with a diminished gag reflex, leading to dysphagia and dysarthria.


•Vestibular nucleus: Nystagmus, diplopia, vertigo, and nausea.

•Descending sympathetic tract: Ipsilateral Horner‘s syndrome, characterized by miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis.



 

Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 285,315 .

questions.text: Which of the following hormone acts via this pathway?
questions.solution:
The image illustrates the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, which is linked to tyrosine kinase receptors. Among the listed hormones, leptin utilizes this pathway.

Hormones that signal through receptor tyrosine kinases or the JAK-STAT pathway include:

- Growth hormone
- Fibroblast growth factor
- Hepatocyte growth factor
- Insulin
- Insulin-like growth factor-1
- Leptin
- Prolactin
- Vascular endothelial growth factor

Leptin, a hormone produced by fat cells, plays a key role in regulating appetite and energy balance. Its receptor functions through the tyrosine kinase activity of the Janus kinase (JAK) family, specifically JAK2. When leptin binds to the extracellular domain of its receptor, it triggers the phosphorylation (P) and activation of JAK2 on the intracellular side. This leads to the phosphorylation of signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT) proteins, which in turn promotes the transcription of specific target genes and protein synthesis.

Additionally, JAK2 phosphorylation activates other intracellular signaling pathways, including the mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPK) and phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) pathways.

 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 63,64,319,326 .

choices.text: Rectal temperature is lower than axillary temperature
Rectal temperature is ideal for measuring the core body temperature
Rectal temperature is higher than tympanic membrane temperature
Oral temperature is lower than rectal temperature.

questions.text: Which of the following options is false regarding the measurement of temperature in a febrile patient?
questions.solution:
Rectal temperature represents the core body temperature and is less affected by changes in environmental temperature. It remains relatively constant. In comparison, oral temperature is typically 0.5°C lower than rectal temperature. However, the oral temperature can be influenced by various factors such as consuming hot or cold fluids, chewing gum, smoking, and breathing through the mouth.

Tympanic membrane thermometers measure radiant heat emitted by the tympanic membrane and the nearby ear canal, providing an absolute value of temperature. Tympanic membrane readings are generally 0.8°C (1.6°F) lower than rectal temperatures. The axillary temperature


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 310 .

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is false about male sexual development?
1. Wolffian duct develops into epididymis and vas deferens on either side of the body.
2. Dihydrotestosterone leads to the development of secondary sexual characteristics and external genitalia.
3. At eight weeks the embryo is bipotent.
4. Mullerian inhibiting substance inhibits the Mullerian duct.
questions.solution:
The embryo remains bipotent until seven weeks of gestation, not eight. By the seventh week, the embryo contains both male and female primordial genital ducts. In a female fetus, the Müllerian duct develops into the uterine tubes and uterus. In a male fetus, the Wolffian duct system on each side forms the epididymis and vas deferens.

Testosterone, produced by the Leydig cells of the fetal testes, and Müllerian inhibiting substance (MIS), secreted by the Sertoli cells, play crucial roles. MIS, an amino acid in the transforming growth factor B (TGF-B) family, induces apoptosis in the Müllerian ducts on the side of its secretion.

Dihydrotestosterone, a derivative of testosterone, is responsible for the development of male external genitalia and secondary sex characteristics. Testosterone also drives the formation of the vas deferens, epididymis, and other structures from the Wolffian ducts.

 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 387,388 .

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are true about skeletal muscle?
A. Contraction does not rely on extracellular calcium.
B. Mitochondria are not the primary source of calcium release.
C. The sarcoplasmic reticulum is the main source of calcium release.
D. The voltage-gated calcium channel on the sarcolemma does not contribute to excitation-contraction coupling.
questions.solution:
•The release of calcium from the sarcoplasmic reticulum is a key aspect of skeletal muscle function.
•Excitation-contraction coupling describes the mechanism where muscle fiber membrane depolarization (excitation) results in muscle contraction.
•To achieve maximum skeletal muscle contraction, the action potentials must penetrate deeply into the muscle fiber to reach the myofibrils. This deep penetration is facilitated by the action potentials traveling along transverse tubules (T tubules), which extend through the muscle fiber from one side to the other.
•The sarcoplasmic reticulum stores calcium ions at high concentrations within its vesicular tubules. When an action potential travels along the adjacent T tubule, it triggers the release of calcium ions from these vesicles into the sarcoplasm surrounding the myofibrils, leading to muscle contraction.
•When the action potential reaches the T tubule, it activates dihydropyridine receptors connected to calcium release channels. The activation of these receptors causes the opening of the calcium release channels, allowing calcium ions to flow into the sarcoplasm and induce contraction.
•In skeletal muscles, extracellular calcium contributes partially to the maintenance of muscle contraction.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 105 .

questions.text: Cells with smooth endoplasmis reticulum secrete-
questions.solution:
Cells that produce steroid hormones extensively feature smooth endoplasmic reticulum.

The endoplasmic reticulum consists of a complex network of tubules within the cell‘s cytoplasm.

In the rough (granular) endoplasmic reticulum, ribosomes are attached to the cytoplasmic side of the membrane. This structure is responsible for protein synthesis, initial folding of polypeptide chains, and the formation of disulfide bonds.

Ribosomes are not present in the smooth (agranular) endoplasmic reticulum, but free ribosomes are found in the cytoplasm. The smooth ER is involved in steroid synthesis in steroid-secreting cells and in detoxification processes in other cells.

The sarcoplasmic reticulum, a specialized form of endoplasmic reticulum, serves as an intracellular calcium reservoir. It releases calcium into the cytoplasm, which stimulates processes such as cell contraction, proliferation, and migration.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 43,44 .

questions.text: At which volume or capacity, pressure measured at the upper airway becomes zero?
questions.solution:
At functional residual capacity (FRC), the pressure measured in the upper airway drops to zero.

The pressure-volume curve, which plots airway pressure against lung volume, helps us understand how the lungs and chest wall work together. This curve shows the relationship between lung compliance and chest wall compliance and is measured using a spirometer.

Functional residual capacity is the amount of air left in the lungs after a normal exhalation, usually around 2.5 liters. When the lungs are at this volume, they are in a relaxed state, and the pressure inside the lungs is effectively zero.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 617.

questions.text:
Arrange the following bands in the sarcomere from the periphery to the center.
A. Z line
B. M line
C. A band
D. H zone
questions.solution:
The correct order of bands in the sarcomere, from the outer edge to the center, is: Z line > A band > H zone > M line.

IThe sarcomere is the fundamental contractile unit of the skeletal muscle fiber.

• The Z line anchors the actin filaments, and the region between two adjacent Z lines is referred to as the sarcomere. It consists of both thick and thin filaments:

- Thick filament: Myosin
- Thin filaments: Actin, tropomyosin, and troponin

• The I band is isotropic to light and contains only actin filaments.

• The A band is anisotropic to light and includes myosin as well as overlapping actin filaments.


• The H band is a lighter region in the center of the A band where the thick filaments do not overlap with the thin filaments when the muscle is relaxed.

• The M line, located at the center of the H band, features slender cross-connections that maintain the organization of the thick filaments.


Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 100-102 .

questions.text: Which of the following are incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
Motilin is a gastrointestinal hormone secreted by enterochromaffin cells and Mo cells in the stomach, small intestine, and colon. It acts via G-protein-coupled receptors on enteric neurons in the duodenum and colon, promoting smooth muscle contraction in the stomach and intestines between meals. M cells, on the other hand, are microfold cells found in the mucosa-associated lymphoid tissues of the small intestine, such as Peyer‘s patches, and are involved in transporting luminal antigens to lymphoid follicles to trigger an immune response.

Gastrin is produced by G cells located in the antrum, duodenum, and jejunum, and it stimulates gastric acid secretion and mucosal growth.


Secretin is secreted by S cells in the duodenum and primarily functions to stimulate the secretion of bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice by the pancreas and duodenum.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 459 .

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for fetal heart acceleration?
questions.solution:
• Amongst the given options, the best answer for the site responsible for Fetal heart acceleration is Carotid body chemoreceptors>Aortic baroreceptors>Autonomic brain stem regulation.
 
  • Though the brainstem is critical to mediating this reflex, the primary stimulus for initiating the changes in the heart rate is initiated by the carotid chemo and baro receptors, especially the chemoreceptor which is highly sensitive to the changes in O02 levels in the blood. It plays a permissive role on fetal heart rate acceleration.
 
  • Arterial chemoreceptors in the carotid arteries>aortic arch, respond to low pH levels and decreased oxygen saturation. These chemoreceptors detect instances of significant fall in blood oxygen levels, setting off the peripheral chemoreflex and heightening both parasympathetic and sympathetic neural activities.
  • The activation of the parasympathetic branch leads to a swift decline in Fetal Heart Rate (FHR), a clinical manifestation identified as intrapartum decelerations. Concurrently, the sympathetic branch prompts significant peripheral vasoconstriction across a range of vascular territories, which results in the elevation of arterial blood pressure, ensuring continuous perfusion to essential organs.
 
  • The permissive action on the FHR acceleration comes in instances of alleviated hypoxemia, detected by the chemoreceptors in the carotid body and aortic arch, suppressing the peripheral chemoreflex, leading to a reduction in parasympathetic and sympathetic neural activities.
  • Deactivation of the parasympathetic branch results in a swift increase in Fetal Heart Rate (FHR), typically seen clinically as an increase in intrapartum accelerations.



Reference: Armstrong M, Kerndt CC, Moore RA. Physiology, Baroreceptors. [Updated 2023 Mar 6]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK538172/

questions.text: Our bodies are designed to detect harmful substances through the perception of bitter taste. Which of the following substances is responsible for this bitter taste?
questions.solution:
Alkaloids produce a very bitter taste, leading to the rejection of the food. Bitter taste sensations are attributed to two main types of substances:

• Long-chain organic compounds containing nitrogen
. • Alkaloids

Alkaloids are responsible for an intensely bitter flavor that causes the rejection of certain foods. They are present in many medicinal drugs, including quinine, caffeine, strychnine, and nicotine. The bitter taste associated with many dangerous toxins in poisonous plants is also due to alkaloids, which helps in avoiding the harmful food.

Sweet taste results from chemicals such as sugars, glycols, alcohols, aldehydes, ketones, amides, esters, some amino acids, certain small proteins, sulfonic acids, halogenated acids, and inorganic salts of lead and beryllium.

Sour taste is caused by acids, with the intensity of the sourness being directly related to the strength of the acid.



Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook Of Medical Physiology, 14th Edition, page no 674,675  .

questions.text: The type of hypoxia based on the graph is-
questions.solution:
The graph illustrates the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve comparing anemic hypoxia with normal conditions. The X-axis represents the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2), while the Y-axis shows the percentage saturation between hemoglobin and oxygen.

There are two lines on the graph: a dotted line representing normal hemoglobin levels and a solid line for reduced hemoglobin levels. The dotted line indicates arterial blood oxygen content of around 19 mL/dL and venous blood oxygen content of 14 mL/dL. In contrast, the solid line reflects an arterial oxygen content of 9 mL/dL and venous oxygen content of 4 mL/dL.

This situation highlights a 50% reduction in hemoglobin's oxygen saturation, even though the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) remains normal. This condition is known as anemic hypoxia.

In anemic hypoxia, the blood's oxygen content is reduced. Patients may not experience issues at rest due to an increase in 2,3-DPG within red blood cells. However, during physical activity, they may struggle because of a limited ability to increase oxygen delivery (QO) to active tissues.

Factors that cause a rightward shift in the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve (seen in metabolically active tissues with increased oxygen demand) include:

- Hypoxia
- Hypercarbia
- Decreased pH
- Increased temperature
- Increased 2,3-biphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG)

Factors that cause a leftward shift in the curve include:

- Increased oxygen
- Decreased carbon dioxide
- Increased pH
- Decreased temperature
- Decreased 2,3-biphosphoglycerate (2,3-BPG)
- Fetalhemoglobin.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 638,639 .

questions.text:
Assertion: RMP is dependent on proteins and phosphate ions.
Reason: Diffusion potential can be calculated using the Nernst Equation. RMP – Resting membrane potential
1. The assertion is independently a false statement, but the reason is independently a true statement
2. The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reason is independently a false statement.
3. Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.
4. Both assertion and reason are independently true and the reason is not the correct explanation for the assertion.
questions.solution:
Both the assertion and reason are independently true, but the reason does not explain the assertion.

Resting membrane potential (RMP) refers to the difference in electrical potential between the cell‘s cytoplasm and the extracellular space. It represents an equilibrium where the concentration gradients of ions across the membrane are balanced by opposing electrical gradients.

RMP is mainly influenced by sodium (Na+) and potassium (K+) ions, along with negatively charged intracellular proteins and organic phosphates. In neurons, potassium concentration is higher inside the cell, while sodium is more concentrated outside. This concentration difference is maintained by the Na+/K+ ATPase pump. Potassium ions move passively out of the cell, whereas sodium ions move in.

The resting membrane potential is calculated using the Goldman-Hodgkin-Katz equation, which accounts for the involvement of multiple ions. Potassium, due to its higher conductance across the membrane at rest, is the primary contributor to the RMP.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 6,8,9 .

choices.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure
Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure.

questions.text: Increase in blood pressure at the beginning of valsalvamaneuver is due to-
questions.solution:
The initial rise in blood pressure during the Valsalva maneuver is due to the increased intrathoracic pressure, which adds to the aortic pressure. The Valsalva maneuver involves forceful expiration against a closed glottis, commonly occurring during actions like coughing, defecation, and heavy lifting. At the start of straining, blood pressure increases because the elevated intrathoracic pressure adds to the pressure in the aorta. However, the pressure then drops as the high intrathoracic pressure compresses the veins, reducing cardiac output.

When the glottis opens and intrathoracic pressure returns to normal, cardiac output is restored. However, peripheral blood vessels constrict, causing a temporary rise in blood pressure above normal levels. This activates the baroreceptors, leading to bradycardia and a subsequent decrease in blood pressure back to normal.


 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 580,581 .

questions.text: Windkessel effect is shown by all except-
questions.solution:
The Windkessel effect is observed in all arteries except the radial artery.

This effect is prominent in large elastic arteries such as the aorta, carotid, and renal arteries. The elasticity, or Windkessel effect, is a unique characteristic of large, elastic vessels. When these vessels are stretched, they undergo elastic recoil. During systole, the aorta expands, temporarily storing blood and allowing more to enter. This stored blood is then released during diastole, ensuring continuous organ perfusion even when the heart is at rest.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1381 .

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents with unconsciousness. His urine is subjected to a test and the results are shown below. What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis. Rothera‘s test, as shown in the image, is a specific test used to detect the presence of ketone bodies in urine.

Type 1 diabetes mellitus is characterized by low insulin levels, leading to increased conversion of fatty acids into acetyl-CoA, which in turn results in elevated ketone body production. Ketosis can be confirmed by detecting ketone bodies in the urine using Rothera's test.

The test involves saturating 5 mL of urine with solid ammonium sulfate. A few drops of freshly prepared sodium nitroprusside are then added, followed by 2 mL of liquor ammonia poured along the sides of the test tube. The formation of a purple ring indicates the presence of ketone bodies. Similar strip tests based on this principle are also available.



Reference : DM Vasudevan Textbook Of Biochemistry for Medical Students, 7th Edition, Page no 138,166,365,429 .

questions.text: The template DNA strand is 5‘CATTCAATATCGATC3‘.The resulting mRNA sequence after transcription is
questions.solution:
The mRNA sequence produced from this template DNA fragment will be 5'GAUCGAUAUUGAAUG3'.

The non-template strand, also known as the coding strand or sense/plus strand, will have the same sequence as the RNA produced, except that thymine (T) in the DNA is replaced by uracil (U) in RNA.

Since all sequences are typically written in the 5' to 3' direction unless specified otherwise, the RNA sequence GAUCGAUAUUGAAUG corresponds to the DNA sequence CATTCAATATCGATC on the non-template strand. Both the RNA and the non-template strand are complementary to the template strand.


 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 349,354 .

questions.text: Xanthurenic aciduria is seen in which of the following vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Xanthurenic aciduria is seen in deficiency of vitamin B6 (pyridoxal phosphate), a coenzyme required by kynureninase enzyme to convert 3-OH kynurenine to 3-OH anthranilic acid during tryptophan metabolism.

 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 288,533-538 .

questions.text:
Which of the following methods can detect the alterations in DNA sequence?
A. Restriction fragment length analysis
B. Flow cytometry
C. Pyrosequencing
D. FISH
questions.solution:
Alterations in DNA sequences can be detected through restriction fragment length analysis and pyrosequencing.

Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP), also known as the cleaved amplified polymorphic sequence (CAPS) assay, is a technique used to distinguish organisms based on variations in their DNA sequences. It involves cutting a specific region of DNA with known variability using restriction enzymes, followed by separating the resulting DNA fragments via agarose gel electrophoresis. The number and relative sizes of the fragments are then determined.

Pyrosequencing is a DNA sequencing method based on the synthesis approach. It uses four enzymatic reactions in a single tube to track DNA synthesis. As nucleotides are added to the reaction, pyrophosphate (PPi) is released. This PPi initiates a series of reactions that produce light, with the amount of light being proportional to the amount of DNA and the number of nucleotides incorporated. The light generated is detected and recorded as a peak signal by a detection system, reflecting the activity of all four enzymes involved in the reaction.

 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 64,65,441 .

questions.text: Ketone bodies are not utilised by the liver because it lacks:
questions.solution:
The liver does not utilize ketone bodies because it lacks the enzyme thiophorase.

Ketone bodies are produced in the liver's mitochondria through ketogenesis and are transported via the blood to peripheral tissues for use. The process of ketone body utilization involves the following steps:

1. Beta-hydroxybutyrate, the most common ketone body, is oxidized to acetoacetate by the enzyme beta-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase, producing NADH.

2. Acetoacetate is then converted to acetoacetyl CoA by transferring a CoA molecule from succinyl CoA via the enzyme succinyl CoA-acetoacetyl CoA transferase (thiophorase).

3. Acetoacetyl CoA is then split into two acetyl CoA molecules by the enzyme thiolase, which are further oxidized to CO2 in the TCA cycle.

Thiokinase (also known as acyl-CoA synthetase) catalyzes the only energy-consuming step in fatty acid oxidation. In the presence of ATP and coenzyme A, thiokinase converts fatty acids into acyl-CoA, the active form of fatty acids. This reaction uses one high-energy phosphate, producing AMP and PPi.

When ketone bodies are present in higher-than-normal levels in the blood or urine, the conditions are known as ketonemia and ketonuria, respectively, and the overall condition is called ketosis. In pathological states such as starvation and diabetes mellitus, the excessive production of ketone bodies leads to ketosis. The ongoing buffering and excretion of ketone bodies deplete the body's alkali reserves, resulting in ketoacidosis.

 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 207-211 .

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are false about collagen?
1. Prolysyl and lysyl hydroxylase are involved in post translational modification
2. Most common fibrous protein
3. Triple helix structure is important for its function
4. Phenylalanine is the most abundant AA in its structure
questions.solution:
Glycine, not phenylalanine, is the most abundant amino acid in collagen.

Collagen is the most abundant protein in the animal kingdom and features a triple helical structure, forming a right-handed superhelix. A unique characteristic of collagen is the presence of glycine at every third position in the sequence.

Proline and hydroxyproline contribute to the rigidity of the collagen molecule. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are formed through post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine, catalyzed by the enzymes prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase. These enzymes require ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and alpha-ketoglutarate as cofactors. Collagen molecules are arranged in a quarter-staggered fashion and further stabilized by covalent cross-links, which provide structural integrity.


 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 592-595 .

questions.text: The thermic effect is highest in-
questions.solution:
The thermic effect is highest for proteins.

The specific dynamic allowance (SDA), also known as the thermic effect of food, refers to the increased heat production or rise in metabolic rate following food intake (diet-induced thermogenesis).

The SDA values are as follows:
•30% for proteins: This means that 30% of the energy from protein consumption is used in its own metabolism, leaving 70% available for useful work.
•15% for lipids
•5% for carbohydrates

Importance: It is commonly observed that after consuming a protein-rich meal during hot weather, people tend to feel warm and uncomfortable for a while. Conversely, in cold weather, such a meal provides a sense of warmth and comfort.

The energy from macronutrient metabolism is used in three key processes in the body:
- Resting metabolic rate
- The thermic effect of food (formerly known as specific dynamic action)
- Physical activity



Reference : DM Vasudevan Textbook of Biochemistry for Medical Students, 7th Edition, Page no 529 .

questions.text: In Pompe‘s disease, the enzyme deficient is?
questions.solution:
Pompe‘s disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme lysosomal alpha-glucosidase

Pompe‘s disease, also known as Type II glycogen storage disorder, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase or lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase. This disorder is rapidly progressive, leading to symptoms such as hypotonia and hepatosplenomegaly. The involvement of the heart muscle (myocardium) distinguishes Pompe‘s disease from other glycogen storage disorders.

Hepatomegaly in Pompe‘s disease is due to the accumulation of glycogen in ballooned lysosomes, which gives the cells a characteristic lacy cytoplasmic appearance. Cardiac and skeletal muscles exhibit enlargement and contain clear spaces filled with glycogen in the lysosomes. While this condition typically has a poor prognosis, recent advancements in enzyme replacement therapy have improved survival rates.

 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 167 .

questions.text: A patient came with complaints of muscle weakness to the OPD. The doctor found that he has cardiomyopathy and diagnosed him to be a case of Barth Syndrome, where the patient has mitochondrial dysfunction. What is the defect in this patient?
questions.solution:
Decreased levels or altered metabolism of cardiolipin result in mitochondrial dysfunction, as observed in Barth syndrome (cardioskeletal myopathy). This condition is characterized by an enlarged and weakened heart (dilated cardiomyopathy), weakness in muscles used for movement (skeletal myopathy), recurrent infections due to low white blood cell counts (neutropenia), and short stature.

Cardiolipin, also known as diphosphatidyl glycerol, is a phospholipid found exclusively in the mitochondria. It is notable for its antigenic properties and can cause a false-positive result in the VDRL test.

This phospholipid is crucial for the inner mitochondrial membrane, where it plays a key role in:

° Ensuring the optimal function of various mitochondrial enzymes involved in energy metabolism.

Preserving the structural integrity of the mitochondrial membrane.


 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st edition, Page no 118,200,201,230 .

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of Karyotyping in the correct order :
A. Collect cells by peripheral vein using a heparin syringe.
B. Culture in phytohaemoagglutinin.
C. Incubation at 37 degrees C for 3 days.
D. Harvest with colchicine.
E. Routine staining with Giemsa
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of steps for karyotyping is as follows:

1. Collect cells via a peripheral vein using a heparinized syringe.


2. Culture the cells with phytohemagglutinin.


3. Incubate at 37°C for 3 days.


4. Harvest the cells using colchicine.


5. Perform routine staining with Giemsa.



Karyotyping is a technique used to isolate, stain, and examine chromosomes to identify chromosomal abnormalities. It is applied in prenatal diagnosis, investigating repeated pregnancy loss, diagnosing suspected chromosomal disorders in children and adults, and classifying lymphomas and leukemias for accurate diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment.

Various techniques are employed in karyotyping to study chromosomes. Different staining methods yield various results and enhance our understanding of the chromosomes. Common techniques include:

Q-banding: Fluorescence staining with quinacrine mustard

G-banding: Giemsa staining following partial denaturation of chromatin

R-banding: Reverse Giemsa staining, where light and dark bands are inverted

C-banding: Staining of heterochromatin with silver salts

T-banding: Staining of chromosome telomeres

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 164-165 .

questions.text: A patient underwent a hysterectomy and was given morphine in the post-operative period and in the ward for pain. She now presents with respiratory depression and pin point pupils. What is the drug used to treatThis condition?
questions.solution:
Naloxone is a competitive antagonist at mu-opioid receptors and quickly reverses opioid toxicity effects when given. It is the drug of choice for addressing opioid overdose, characterized by a triad of coma, respiratory depression, and pinpoint pupils (miosis), along with hypotension, bradycardia, shallow breathing, and hypothermia. While naloxone is a pure opioid antagonist that counteracts all effects of opioid toxicity except sedation, it is also employed to reverse neonatal asphyxia caused by opioid use during labor.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 213-218,166,449-456,461 .

questions.text: Drug used for trastuzumab-resistant her 2 positive breast cancer Is:
questions.solution:
Lapatinib is a small-molecule, orally bioavailable inhibitor of the EGFR and HER2 tyrosine kinases, and is metabolized by CYP3A4. It is approved for treating metastatic HER2-positive breast cancer that is resistant to trastuzumab when used in combination with capecitabine. Additionally, lapatinib, in combination with the aromatase inhibitor letrozole, is used to treat hormone receptor-positive, metastatic breast cancer that overexpresses HER2 in postmenopausal women. Common side effects include acneiform rash, diarrhea, cramping, and worsening of gastroesophageal reflux. While cardiac toxicity is generally less severe compared to trastuzumab, lapatinib should be used cautiously with other cardiotoxic drugs. It has been associated with a dose-dependent prolongation of the QT interval, so careful monitoring is necessary for patients with heart conditions. Severe hepatotoxicity has also been reported. Trastuzumab, a monoclonal antibody that targets the HER2 receptor, is used to treat HER2-positive breast cancer.



 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 956,1340,1378,1389 .

questions.text: Nomogram used for vancomycin dosing is:
questions.solution:
• The Matzke nomogram is utilized for determining vancomycin dosing.
  • It provides dosing intervals from 0.5 to 12 days, depending on creatinine clearance (CL) values ranging from 0 to 120 mL/min. This tool helps establish the initial empiric dose and interval for intravenous (IV) vancomycin in hospitalized adults who are not undergoing hemodialysis.
 
  • However, it is not suitable for patients with highly variable vancomycin pharmacokinetics, including critically ill individuals, those with severe burn injuries (over 20% of body surface), patients with rapidly changing renal function, pregnant women, individuals with liver failure or ascites, those at extreme weights, recent transplant recipients, and cystic fibrosis patients.
  • The Rumack-Matthew nomogram evaluates potential hepatotoxicity based on serum acetaminophen concentration relative to the time elapsed since ingestion, after a single acute dose of acetaminophen.



Reference: Rybak, M J, and S C Boike. “Individualized adjustment of vancomycin dosage: comparison with two dosage nomograms.” Drug intelligence & clinical pharmacy vol. 20,1 (1986): 64-8. doi:10.1177/106002808602000112. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3943460/

choices.text: It can cause fine tremors in the therapeutic range
It is not absorbed from the stomach
Approved for the treatment of absent seizures

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding lithium?
questions.solution:
Lithium is known to potentially cause fine tremors even when administered within the therapeutic range. Its therapeutic index is very narrow.

A fine tremor is a common side effect at therapeutic doses of lithium. This tremor typically affects the arms symmetrically, is nonprogressive, and does not worsen. In contrast, tremors due to lithium toxicity are coarser, more disabling, may involve the legs, and are accompanied by other signs of toxicity. Additional adverse effects include mental confusion, hypothyroidism, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and edema. Lithium use during early pregnancy can lead to Ebstein anomaly in the fetus and may result in neonatal goiter, CNS depression, hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), and cardiac murmurs.

In cases of lithium overdose or toxicity, hemodialysis is an effective treatment since lithium is readily dialyzed.

Lithium, a mood stabilizer, is administered orally and is almost completely absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract. It is the first-line treatment for bipolar disorder, including the management of mania, and has anti-suicidal properties. Due to its narrow therapeutic index, monitoring is essential; therapeutic drug levels are measured 12 hours after the last dose to ensure safety and efficacy.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 375-380 .

questions.text:
Match the following
Column I Column II
A Mirabegron 1 Beta 1
B Indacaterol 2 Beta 
C Betaxolol 3 Beta 2
D Isoproterenol 4 Beta 3
questions.solution:
Mirabegron is a beta 3-adrenergic receptor agonist used to treat bladder incontinence. It works by activating this receptor in the bladder, leading to relaxation of the detrusor muscle and increased bladder capacity. This action helps prevent urination and provides relief for individuals with an overactive bladder or urinary incontinence.

Indacaterol is a very long-acting beta-2 agonist (V-LABA) used for the maintenance treatment of COPD and is effective with once-daily dosing.

Betaxolol is a selective third-generation beta-blocker (beta 1-selective) that also blocks calcium entry and has slight membrane-stabilizing properties, but no agonist activity. Isoproterenol, on the other hand, is a non-selective beta agonist (?1 = ?2) with no alpha activity. It directly stimulates ?1 receptors in the heart, increasing the risk of tachycardia and arrhythmias. The reduction in peripheral vascular resistance, caused by ?2 stimulation, leads to a drop in diastolic blood pressure. Isoproterenol is sometimes used as a cardiac stimulant in patients with bradycardia.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 277,278,280 .

choices.text: Ratio of median lethal dose in 50% of population to median effective dose in 50% of population
Denotes safety and efficacy in an individual
Denotes safety and efficacy in the population
Denotes safety and efficacy after experiments on humans

questions.text: True about the therapeutic index of a drug is:
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index of a drug indicates its safety and effectiveness for the population, rather than for individuals. It is determined using the equation:

Therapeutic Index (TI) = LD50 / ED50

This index, also known as the therapeutic ratio, reflects the relationship between doses that cause lethal or toxic effects and the dose that provides therapeutic benefits. It is used to evaluate a drug's safety profile.

Mathematically, TI can be expressed as:

TI = LD50 / ED50 or TD50 / ED50

where LD50 represents the median lethal dose, TD50 denotes the median toxic dose, and ED50 is the median effective dose.

Median lethal dose (LD50) and median toxic dose (TD50):

LD50 is the dose at which 50% of experimental animals die.

In human trials, TD50 is used, representing the dose causing adverse effects in 50% of the population.


A higher LD50 or TD50 implies a safer drug.

Median effective dose (ED50):

ED50 is the dose at which 50% of experimental animals exhibit the desired therapeutic effect.

It is the amount of drug needed to achieve the desired effects in 50% of the population.


The therapeutic window refers to the range of drug concentrations where efficacy is high and the risk of adverse effects is low.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 53,54 .

questions.text: Osimertinib is used in NSCLC with which of the following mutations?
questions.solution:
The T790M mutation in the EGFR gene is known to confer resistance to first and second-generation EGFR inhibitors. Osimertinib, a third-generation EGFR inhibitor, is effective against this resistance and is commonly used for patients with the T790M mutation who have progressed on earlier EGFR inhibitors.

Osimertinib is a kinase inhibitor approved for:

Treating patients with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) that has progressed after prior EGFR TKI treatment and is positive for the EGFR T790M mutation.

Serving as a first-line treatment for metastatic NSCLC and as adjuvant therapy following resection of NSCLC with EGFR exon 19 deletions or exon 21 L858R mutations.


Although osimertinib is used for both the L858R and T790M mutations, it is particularly noted for its efficacy against the T790M mutation due to its ability to overcome resistance associated with earlier EGFR inhibitors.

Osimertinib is taken orally, is a substrate of CYP3A, and is primarily excreted through feces with some excretion in urine. Concurrent use of CYP3A4 inducers may require dose adjustments
Common adverse effects include leukopenia,
diarrhea, skin rash, interstitial lung disease, QTcprolongation, and left ventricular dysfunction.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 1385,1386 .

questions.text: The anti-diabetic medication that lowers HbA1C by increasing GIP and GLP-1 levels and reducing glucagon levels is an oral drug that decreases both pre- and post-prandial glucose levels. This drug is:
questions.solution:
Alogliptin is a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitor. Incretins such as glucagon-like peptide (GLP) and glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide (GIP) stimulate insulin secretion into the bloodstream, but they are quickly inactivated by dipeptidyl peptidase. By inhibiting dipeptidyl peptidase, alogliptin enhances the effects of these incretins, leading to increased insulin release. DPP-4 inhibitors thus improve postprandial insulin release, reduce glucagon levels, and help lower both mealtime and fasting glucose levels.

Other DPP-4 inhibitors include saxagliptin, linagliptin, alogliptin, and vildagliptin, all of which are weight-neutral. These drugs are known to cause severe joint pain, which typically resolves after discontinuation. Linagliptin is primarily eliminated through the hepatobiliary system, with minimal renal clearance. Saxagliptin is metabolized by the liver and should be used at reduced doses if administered with a cytochrome P450 enzyme inhibitor. The other DPP-4 inhibitors are excreted through the kidneys, so they should be used with caution in patients with renal insufficiency.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 1035-1041 .

questions.text: A patient was started on a drug for mood disorder and he developed priapism. The causative drug is:
What is true about KEYNOTE-189 trial?
questions.solution:
• The KEYNOTE-189 trial is a study designed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of pembrolizumab (MK-3475) in combination with pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy, compared to pemetrexed/platinum chemotherapy alone.
  • This trial focuses on patients with advanced or metastatic non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who have not had prior systemic treatment for their advanced disease.
  • Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either pembrolizumab with pemetrexed/platinum or pemetrexed/platinum alone.






Reference: Pembrolizumab plus Chemotherapy in Metastatic Non-small Cell Lung Cancer (NEJM article), Leena Gandhi et al., Published in 2018, DOI: 10.1056/NEJMoa1801005. URL: https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa1801005

questions.text: Cyclosporine-induced cholestasis is due to which receptor?
questions.solution:
Cyclosporine-induced cholestasis is linked to the MDR1 transporter.

ABC transporters such as MRP2, MDR1, BCRP, BSEP, and MDR3, located in the bile canalicular membrane of hepatocytes, facilitate the efflux of drugs, their metabolites, bile salts, and phospholipids from the liver into bile, against a steep concentration gradient. This process, driven by ATP hydrolysis, involves primary active transport.

Cyclosporine, which is a substrate for MDR1, can lead to cholestatic liver injury through several mechanisms:

It competitively inhibits ATP-dependent transporters.

It impairs intrahepatic vesicle transport and disrupts the targeting of ATP-dependent transporters to the canalicular membrane.

It affects bile secretion by increasing canalicular membrane fluidity without altering the expression of canalicular transporters.


Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive drug that works by inhibiting calcineurin activity. It forms a complex with cyclophilin, a cytoplasmic receptor protein, resulting in the cyclosporine-cyclophilin complex. Calcineurin is a calcium/calmodulin-dependent phosphatase essential for T cell lymphokine production and proliferation. The drug-receptor complex binds to and inhibits calcineurin, which, in turn, prevents the translocation of a group of transcription factors (NF-AT). This leads to decreased transcriptional activation of cytokine genes such as interleukin (IL)-2, tumor necrosis factor (TNF)alpha, IL-3, IL-4, CD40L, granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor, and interferon-gamma, ultimately reducing T lymphocyte proliferation and providing immunomodulation.

Cyclosporine is used for:

Preventing organ rejection in solid organ transplants (kidney, liver, and heart).

Treating rheumatoid arthritis when methotrexate is insufficient.

Managing conditions like Behcet‘s disease, acute ocular syndrome, endogenous uveitis, atopic dermatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, and nephrotic syndrome.


Adverse effects of cyclosporine include decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR), metabolic disturbances such as hypomagnesemia, hyperkalemia, dyslipidemia, gynecomastia, and hypertrichosis, as well as neurotoxicity like convulsions. Additionally, patients with psoriasis treated with cyclosporine have an increased risk of skin and lymphoproliferative malignancies.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 92,773-775 .

questions.text: A diabetic patient began taking a medication that reduced her HbA1c from 7.6 to 6.7. She has since reported itching in the vulvovaginal area. Which drug is she most likely using?
questions.solution:
In the described clinical scenario, the most likely cause of itching in the vulvovaginal area is canagliflozin. This medication, a sodium-glucose transporter 2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor, is associated with side effects such as urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the increased glucose content in urine. Other potential side effects include a higher risk of fractures and lower extremity amputations.

Canagliflozin, along with other SGLT-2 inhibitors like dapagliflozin and empagliflozin, works by inhibiting the SGLT-2 transporter located in the proximal renal tubule, which is responsible for reabsorbing 80-90% of filtered glucose. By blocking glucose reabsorption, these drugs lead to glycosuria and alter the renal threshold for glucose.

SGLT-2 inhibitors can also lead to mild weight loss and lower blood pressure. Empagliflozin and canagliflozin have been shown to reduce major cardiovascular events. Common side effects include urinary tract infections and genital mycotic infections due to the glucose in urine. There is also a risk of diabetic ketoacidosis, fractures, and lower limb amputations related to imbalances in minerals, parathormone, and vitamin D. The effectiveness of SGLT-2 inhibitors may diminish in stage 3 kidney disease (GFR 60-30 mL/min) because their action depends on the rate of glucose filtration.


 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1038-1040,1043 .

choices.text: Release of reactive oxygen species and free radicals

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mechanism for thalidomide teratogenicity?
questions.solution:
Thalidomide does not cause teratogenic effects by inhibiting IL2, IL4, or IL5. Instead, its teratogenicity is linked to mechanisms such as oxidative stress, anti-angiogenesis, and its binding to the protein cereblon (CRBN), which is involved in cerebral tissue development and plays a role in memory and learning processes. Exposure to thalidomide during fetal development leads to phocomelia, a condition characterized by underdeveloped limbs, absent pelvic bones, and anomalies such as fused fingers and missing thumbs. Thalidomide was initially used to treat morning sickness during pregnancy but was withdrawn due to these severe effects. It is now prescribed for erythema nodosumleprosum.

Thalidomide functions as an immunomodulator. It is absorbed slowly and variably from the gastrointestinal tract, distributes widely in tissues and organs with minimal plasma protein binding, and is excreted in the urine and, in its non-absorbed form, in the feces.

Common side effects of thalidomide include sedation and constipation. A serious adverse effect is peripheral sensory neuropathy, which presents as asymmetric, painful peripheral paresthesia and sensory loss. Symptoms typically include numbness in the toes and feet, muscle cramps, weakness, signs of pyramidal tract involvement, and carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 1404,1405 .

questions.text: Which is a rare but very severe side effect of clozapine that requires regular monitoring?
questions.solution:
Agranulocytosis, though rare, is a severe side effect of clozapine that necessitates regular monitoring. Patients on clozapine should undergo consistent hematological checks due to the risk of agranulocytosis and should avoid combining clozapine with other drugs that can cause agranulocytosis, such as carbamazepine, phenytoin, propylthiouracil, and sulfonamides.

The adverse effects of clozapine include:

Sedation and weight gain due to H1 receptor antagonism

Syncope, tachycardia, and hypotension from alpha-1 receptor antagonism

Hypersalivation/sialorrhea caused by M4 receptor agonism

Seizures, which are dose-dependent

Agranulocytosis, which is dose-independent


Clozapine can lower the seizure threshold, thereby increasing the risk of seizures. As an atypical antipsychotic, clozapine acts as an antagonist at 5HT2A, D1, D3, D4, and alpha receptors. It is used for treatment-resistant schizophrenia, suicidal patients with schizophrenia, severe psychotic depression, and Huntington‘s disease.

 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 381 .

questions.text: A pregnant woman arrives for an antenatal check-up. She has a history of a stillbirth at 28 weeks in her previous pregnancy and recalls having multiple sexual partners, as well as a painless ulcer on her vulva before her last pregnancy. What should be the initial investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
The Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test should be the initial investigation for this patient, given her history of a stillbirth and a painless genital ulcer, which likely suggests syphilis.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete with distinctive corkscrew-like motility.

Primary syphilis follows the sexual transmission of Treponema pallidum and presents as a painless, non-tender papule on the genitalia that quickly becomes eroded and indurated, forming a hard chancre. It may also be accompanied by lymphadenopathy. The chancre usually heals within 10-40 days even without treatment, leaving a scar.

In untreated syphilitic women, obstetric outcomes may improve with subsequent pregnancies. Initial pregnancies may result in abortions or stillbirths, while later pregnancies may lead to live births with syphilitic manifestations. Ultimately, healthy infants may be born after several pregnancies.

Syphilis can be diagnosed with VDRL and RPR tests, and confirmed with FTA-ABS, TPHA, or TPI testing.

Dark ground microscopy is the most specific and sensitive method for diagnosing syphilis when an active chancre or condylomalata is present. Since the ulcer is inactive in this patient, dark ground microscopy is not appropriate here.

Smear specimens can be stained with Fontana stain, while pathological tissues can be stained using Levaditi stain. The silver impregnation technique is also applicable.


 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 375 .

questions.text:
Match the diseases with their maximum incubation period.
Column I Column II
1 Hepatitis A a 10 days
2 Chickenpox b 90 days
3 SARS c 21 days
4 Syphillis d 50 days
questions.solution:
The incubation period is the duration between the entry of an infectious agent into the body and the onset of the first symptoms or signs.

For syphilis, the incubation period ranges from 10 to 90 days and is inversely related to the size of the Spirochaete inoculum.

SARS infection typically has an incubation period of 5 to 10 days.

Hepatitis A infection has an incubation period ranging from 10 to 50 days, with a common range of 14 to 28 days.

Chickenpox, caused by the varicella zoster virus (HSV-3), has an incubation period of 10 to 21 days.


 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 379,477,563 .

questions.text: ACSF sample of an elderly male presenting with meningitis is subjected to gram staining and revealed gram-positive bacilli. Which of the following is true regarding the motility of the causative agent?**
questions.solution:
The scenario of an elderly male with meningitis and a gram-positive bacillus on smear is indicative of a Listeria infection. Listeria monocytogenes is motile at 25°C and non-motile at 37°C, displaying a characteristic slow tumbling motility at temperatures between 22°C and 28°C. This differential motility is due to the production of peritrichous flagella, which are most effective between 20°C and 30°C.

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacillus that can survive at refrigerator temperatures (4°C), as well as in acidic conditions and high salt environments. This ability allows it to overcome food preservation barriers, making it a significant foodborne pathogen. Its primary virulence factor is listeriolysin O, which helps the bacteria escape from phagocytes and can lead to septicemia.

The bacterium is catalase-positive, does not produce hydrogen sulfide (H2S), and demonstrates beta-hemolysis, which helps differentiate it from other gram-positive bacilli.

Listeria monocytogenes typically enters the body through the consumption of contaminated food such as refrigerated milk, cheese, fruit, or vegetables. While healthy individuals may experience mild, self-limiting febrile gastroenteritis with symptoms including fever, chills, headache, myalgias, abdominal pain, and diarrhea, this illness usually lasts 1-3 days and has an incubation period of 6-48 hours.

 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 402-403 .

choices.text: Information is not enough for the diagnosis

questions.text: An elderly male patient who underwent a kidney transplant 10 years ago is on immunosuppressive therapy. He reports a history of cough and dyspnea for the past week, and sputum microscopy shows gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae. What is the likely diagnosis?**
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and sputum microscopy showing gram-positive budding yeast cells and pseudohyphae are indicative of invasive candidiasis.

Candida is a leading cause of opportunistic fungal infections worldwide. Individuals with compromised immune systems, such as those on immunosuppressive therapy, are at a higher risk for systemic candidiasis, which can include conditions like candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

The most common Candida species involved in these infections are *Candida albicans*, *Candida parapsilosis*, and *Candida glabrata*. Candida infections can present in several forms, including cutaneous and mucosal candidiasis, systemic candidiasis, or, less commonly, chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

Cutaneous and mucosal infections may manifest as oral thrush, characterized by white, patchy or confluent pseudomembranous lesions on the tongue, lips, gums, and palate, and are often associated with AIDS. Candida can also cause vulvovaginitis, affect the nails leading to onychomycosis, and invade the surrounding nail plate.

Morphologically, Candida appears as yeast-like fungi, existing as both yeast and pseudohyphae. On wet films and smears, they appear as budding, gram-positive cells. Mycelial forms suggest colonization, and Candida albicanscan form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.


 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 596,616 .

questions.text: Which of the following is a protozoan parasite, that can be seen inside Kupffer cells?
questions.solution:
The protozoan parasite *Leishmaniadonovani* is known to be found inside Kupffer cells. These cells are part of the mononuclear phagocytic system located in the liver. The amastigote form of *Leishmania*, also called the Leishman-Donovan (LD) body (as shown in the image below), is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes, and other reticuloendothelial cells. It contains a kinetoplast, which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast, but lacks a flagellum.

Leishmaniasis is a gradually progressing disease caused by a protozoan parasite from the genus *Leishmania*. The parasite‘s life cycle has two main forms:

- **Promastigote**: This flagellated form develops and lives extracellularly in the sandfly vector.
- **Amastigote**: This non-flagellated form multiplies intracellularly within the host‘s reticuloendothelial cells.

Transmission occurs through the bite of an infected female Phlebotomussandfly, which introduces the flagellated promastigotes into the host‘s skin. The disease presents with symptoms such as fever with chills, splenomegaly, and hepatomegaly. It weakens the immune system, leading to persistent fever, anemia, and enlargement of the liver and spleen. If untreated, it can result in death due to secondary infections.

Diagnosis of leishmaniasis primarily involves the demonstration of amastigotes inside macrophages from tissue aspirates, such as blood smears, bone marrow, spleen, or lymph node aspirates. This method is considered the gold standard for diagnosis.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1744-1745 .

questions.text: Which of the following organism is transferred by the parasite shown below?
questions.solution:
The trombiculid mite is the vector responsible for transmitting Orientiatsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, also known as chigger-borne typhus. Humans become infected when bitten by the mite‘s larvae, known as chiggers. The disease has an incubation period of 1 to 3 weeks.

Patients typically develop a distinctive eschar at the site of the mite bite, along with regional lymph node swelling (lymphadenopathy) and a maculopapular rash. Symptoms can include fever, headache, and conjunctival injection. In severe cases, complications such as meningoencephalitis, myocarditis, and pneumonia may occur.

Diagnosis is primarily made through serologic assays. One commonly used test is the Weil-Felix reaction, a heterophile agglutination test in which sera are examined for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain *Proteus* strains (OX19, OX2, and OXK). In scrub typhus, only the OXK strain is agglutinated.

The preferred treatment for scrub typhus in both adults and children is doxycycline.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 977 .

questions.text: A lady cleans her cat litter regularly to avoid infection by *Toxoplasma* during her pregnancy. What is the infective stage of this organism in the cat feces?
questions.solution:
The infective stage of Toxoplasmafound in cat feces is the oocyst. Oocysts develop through the sexual reproduction of Toxoplasmain the cat‘s intestinal lumen and are excreted in the feces. These oocysts take 1 to 5 days after excretion to become infective. Therefore, removing cat litter daily and disposing of it safely can help prevent infection.

In cats, the definitive hosts, both asexual reproduction (schizogony) and sexual reproduction (gametogony) occur. The oocyst is formed through sexual reproduction, while tachyzoites and tissue cysts represent stages of asexual multiplication.

In intermediate hosts, such as humans, mice, and rats, only the asexual forms—tachyzoites and tissue cysts—are found.


Reference : Paniker’s Textbook Of Medical Parasitology, 8th Edition, Page no 90-93 .

choices.text: Category C – Emerging diseases that are easy to disseminate and are associated with high mortality rates
Category A – Easily transmitted and are associated with high mortality rates
Category B – Moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with low mortality rates
Category D – Re-emerging diseases that are high priority agents

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement according to the CDC classification of bioterrorism agents?
questions.solution:
Bioterrorism refers to the deliberate release or threat of release of biological agents, including viruses, bacteria, fungi, or their toxins, with the aim of causing disease or death among humans, livestock, or food crops. The goal is often to incite fear among the population or exert pressure on governments.

The CDC classifies bioterrorism agents into three categories:
 
  • Category A: These agents are highly transmissible from person to person and are associated with high mortality rates. They have the potential to cause significant public health emergencies.
 
  • Category B: Agents in this category are moderately easy to disseminate. They tend to cause moderate levels of illness (morbidity) and low mortality rates.
 
  • Category C: These are emerging pathogens, such as Nipah virus and Hantavirus, that could potentially be engineered for large-scale dissemination in the future. They are concerning due to their availability, high morbidity and mortality rates, and ease of production and dissemination.

There is no Category D in the CDC‘s classification system for bioterrorism agents.




Reference: Das, S, and V K Kataria. “Bioterrorism : A Public Health Perspective.” Medical journal, Armed Forces India vol. 66,3 (2010): 255-60. doi:10.1016/S0377-1237(10)80051-6. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4921253/

questions.text: The given image of the cell wall belongs towhich of the following organism?
questions.solution:
An image showing a cell wall with a capsule and lipooligosaccharides (LOS) suggests the presence of Neisseria meningitidis.

Unlike lipopolysaccharides (LPS), LOS lacks a long O-antigen side chain but remains a key virulence factor. It is found in several organisms, including Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus ducreyi.

The genus Neisseria consists of Gram-negative, aerobic, non-sporulating, non-motile, oxidase-positive cocci that typically appear in pairs (diplococci). It includes two major pathogens: Neisseria meningitidis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae. A crucial distinction between them is that N. Meningitidis has a capsule, while N. Gonorrhoeaedoes not.



Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 28th Edition, Page no 29,295,297 .

questions.text: A patient presents with PUO. He is suspected to be suffering from brucellosis. Multiple dilutions of his serum sample are put up for a standard agglutination test. The results came as follows: Negative agglutination for the serum dilutions 1:20 and 1:40; But 1:80 and 1:160 were positive for agglutination. Which of the following is responsible for the negative test in the first 2 dilutions?
questions.solution:
The negative test results observed in the first two tubes are due to the prozone phenomenon, where an excess of antibodies compared to antigens leads to weak or absent precipitation.

The lattice hypothesis explains how precipitation and agglutination reactions occur. The amount of precipitate formed depends significantly on the relative proportions of antigens and antibodies. Precipitation happens when a lattice of alternating antigen and antibody molecules is formed.

Key points related to this phenomenon:

- The prozone phenomenon occurs when there are excessive antibodies in the test system. This results in weak or absent precipitation, leading to a false-negative test result.

- In the zone of equivalence, the antigen and antibody are present in optimal proportions, leading to maximum precipitation and enhanced lattice formation.


- The post-zone phenomenon arises when there are excessive antigens in the test system, also resulting in weak or absent precipitation.

Both the prozone and post-zone phenomena can cause false-negative results in precipitation reactions. These false negatives can be corrected by making serial dilutions of the serum, which optimizes the concentrations of antigens and antibodies in the test system.

 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 107 .

questions.text: A patient presented with a lesion on the left buttock. He has a history of heart transplant 15 years back. Aspirate from the lesion shows gram-positive filamentous bacteria. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario presented involves a local abscess with aspirate findings indicating filamentous, gram-positive bacteria, suggestive of Nocardia species. Nocardia appears as filamentous organisms with extensive branching, and they are aerobic, gram-positive, catalase-positive, and urease-positive. They are weakly acid-fast, which means they stain with carbolfuchsin and retain the stain even after decolorization with 1-4% sulfuric acid, unlike the stronger acid-alcohol decolorizer used for other acid-fast organisms.

Infections caused by Nocardia can manifest as cutaneous, subcutaneous, or systemic lesions, including local abscesses, cellulitis, or lymphocutaneous lesions. Systemic nocardiosis is more common in immunocompromised individuals and often presents as pulmonary disease, such as pneumonia or lung abscesses, resembling tuberculosis. Extrapulmonary manifestations can affect the brain, kidneys, and other organs.

The provided image depicts a smear stained with modified acid-fast Kinyoun staining, showing filamentous, red-stained, partially acid-fast rods consistent with Nocardia

 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 9th edition, Page no 400 .

questions.text: Identify the organism in the given image:
questions.solution:
Microscopy revealing broad, aseptate, ribbon-like hyphae with irregular branching is indicative of mucormycosis. This opportunistic infection, also known as zygomycosis, is primarily caused by species of *Rhizopus* (the most prevalent), *Mucor*, and *Absidia*. The common clinical presentation is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis, characterized by invasion of blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain, leading to thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. The blackish discoloration observed is a result of arterial and venous thrombosis, leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis is confirmed through staining with 10% potassium hydroxide and culture. On Sabouraud agar incubated at 30-37°C, the fungi grow as grey-white colonies with a thick, cottony, fluffy surface. Microscopic examination reveals irregularly branched broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores ending in sporangia containing spores.

In contrast:

- Aspergillus and Talaromyces (formerly known as Penicillium) exhibit septate hyphae with conidiophores.
- Blastomyces is a dimorphic fungus that appears as thick-walled, round yeast cells with single broad-based budding (giving a figure of 8 appearance) at 37°C in body tissues and cultures, and as a filamentous mold at room temperature (25°C).


 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 611,613,614,615 .

questions.text: A microorganism is resistant to meropenem and aminoglycoside and sensitive to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole. What is the likely microorganism?
questions.solution:
Stenotrophomonasmaltophila, formerly known as Pseudomonas maltophila, is an opportunistic pathogen responsible for wound infections, urinary tract infections, and septicemia. This bacterium is known to be sensitive to co-trimoxazole.

Intrinsic resistance refers to a bacterial species‘ natural ability to resist the effects of certain antimicrobial agents due to inherent structural or functional characteristics. This built-in resistance allows the bacteria to tolerate specific drugs or classes of antimicrobials.

Burkholderiacepacia,formerly referred to as Pseudomonas cepacia,is an opportunistic pathogen that can lead to fatal necrotizing pneumonia. Strains within the B. Cepacia complex are intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides, polymyxins, and first- and second-generation cephalosporins. However, they are sensitive to meropenem, co-trimoxazole, doxycycline, minocycline, chloramphenicol, and ceftazidime.


 

Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 322 .

questions.text: A patient with a history of bone marrow transplant presented with a lesion in the lung. On microscopic examination, the lesion is shown below. What is the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described—a lung lesion in a patient with a history of bone marrow transplant—along with the image showing septate hyphae with branching at acute angles, is indicative of Aspergillosis.
 
  • Invasive aspergillosis is caused by Aspergillus species and is commonly seen in immunocompromised patients, with the lungs being the primary site of infection. Symptoms often include fever, productive cough, chest discomfort, hemoptysis, and shortness of breath. The drug of choice for treatment is Voriconazole.
 
  • In addition to invasive aspergillosis, other forms include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (which typically presents with central bronchiectasis), aspergilloma, and superficial infections such as otomycosis or mycotic keratitis.
 
  • Histopathological examination of tissue typically reveals characteristic dichotomous branching at acute angles. The hyphae do not stain well with hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) but are better visualized with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain.
 
  • Diagnosis can also be supported by detecting galactomannan, an Aspergillus cell-wall component, and by culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus produces dark green colonies, Aspergillus niger forms black colonies, and Aspergillus flavus generates yellow-green colonies. Microscopic examination of these colonies, stained with lactophenol cotton blue, reveals septate hyphae and conidiophores.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 613.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is caused by abnormal folding of proteins?
questions.solution:
feldt-Jakob disease is caused due to abnormal folding of proteins.
