Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a prion disease that causes higher cortical function deficits. This infection can be acquired by corneal transplantation, contaminated electroencephalogram (EEG) electrode implantation, dura mater grafts, and contaminated human growth hormone (hGH) preparations.

Symptoms are almost always rapidly progressive, and the clinical presentation includes the following:

• Myoclonus
• Higher cortical deficits

• Psychiatric manifestations – depression, psychosis, and visual hallucinations

• Profound dementia – memory loss, impaired judgment, intellectual decline


• Visual impairment or cerebellar gait and coordination deficits in a few patients

• Nonspecific prodromal symptoms – fatigue, sleep disturbance, weight, loss, headache, anxiety, vertigo, malaise, and ill-defined pain


• Extrapyramidal dysfunction – rigidity, masklike facies, choreoathetoid movements;

• Seizures


• Hypoesthesia

• Supranuclear gaze palsy, optic atrophy


Patients commonly present with myoclonus and dementia. EEG shows characteristic periodic electrical bursts. MRI shows increased intensity in the basal ganglia and cortical ribboning (ribbonlike signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri). On light microscopy, the pathologic hallmarks of CJD are spongiform degeneration and astrocytic gliosis.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3419-3421 .

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy presents to the outpatient department. His peripheral smear shows the presence of smudge cells. Which of the following additional investigations will you do to arrive at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly patient presenting with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy, along with the presence of smudge cells on a peripheral smear, is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). The diagnosis is confirmed through immunophenotyping via flow cytometry. The characteristic immunophenotype of CLL includes CD19+, CD20+, CD23+, and CD5+ markers.

CLL is a peripheral B-cell neoplasm typically seen in adults, especially men. Most patients are asymptomatic at the time of diagnosis. When symptoms do occur, they are often nonspecific, such as easy fatigue, weight loss, and anorexia. Symptomatic patients frequently exhibit generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly.

The chromosomal abnormalities associated with CLL include:

Deletion of 13q (most common, associated with a good prognosis)

Deletion of 11q

Trisomy 12q

Deletion of 17p (linked to poor prognosis)


In a peripheral blood smear, CLL is characterized by small, round lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm. Smudge cells are formed when some of these cells rupture during smear preparation. An absolute lymphocyte count greater than 5000/ml is needed for diagnosis. Hypogammaglobulinemia is often observed, increasing susceptibility to infections. Some patients may also develop hemolyticanemia or thrombocytopenia due to autoantibodies produced by non-neoplastic B cells.

A lymph node biopsy in CLL typically shows small lymphocytes mixed with larger, activated lymphocytes. The larger cells are mitotically active and form loose aggregates known as proliferation centers, which are pathognomonic for CLL.

For asymptomatic patients, expectant management is the preferred approach. The gold standard treatment involves a combination of fludarabine, cyclophosphamide, and rituximab.

A serious complication of CLL is Richter‘s syndrome, where the disease transforms into an aggressive lymphoma, most commonly diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL).

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 597-599 .

choices.text: cryoprecipitate is stored at -20°c with a shelf life of 6 mont
Platelets is stored between 20°c to 24°c with a self life of 5 days
Packed red cells stored with adenine, glucose, mannitol and saline is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 5 weeks
Fresh frozen plasma is stored between -5°C to -15°C with a shelf life of 2 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about blood products?
questions.solution:
Platelets can be stored at temperatures between 20°C and 24°C, with a shelf life of 5 days. These platelet concentrates are used to treat conditions like thrombocytopenia, platelet function defects, disseminated intravascular coagulation, and to prevent dilutional thrombocytopenia during massive blood transfusions or in cases of bone marrow failure. Agitation during storage is crucial for maintaining the viability and function of platelets, as they continue to metabolize glucose and produce lactate at room temperature. Agitation ensures even distribution, prevents clumping, and facilitates gas exchange.

Fresh frozen plasma and cryoprecipitate are typically stored at –30°C. Before use, they are thawed at temperatures between 30°C and 37°C in the blood bank, then transported at ambient temperature to the ward. They must be used immediately after thawing and should not be refrozen.

Whole blood and packed red cells are stored between 2°C and 6°C, and transported between 2°C and 10°C. Packed red cells stored with SAGM (sodium, adenine, glucose, and mannitol) have a shelf life of up to 42 days.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 886,890 .

questions.text: A patient with lytic lesions on the skull is suspected of having Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Which of the following is a characteristic finding on electron microscopy?
questions.solution:
The presence of Birbeck granules in the cytoplasm is a characteristic finding of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) on electron microscopy. These granules have a dilated terminal end that gives them a tennis racket-like appearance. They contain the protein langerin (CD207) and are observed on electron microscopy.
Histopathologically, Langerhans cells feature a single large nucleus with a distinctive folded or grooved appearance, often described as a coffee-bean appearance, and small, inconspicuous nucleoli. The cytoplasm contains Birbeck granules. Tumor cells specifically express the markers HLA-DR, S-100, CD1a, and langerin (CD207).
Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is caused by the proliferation of immature dendritic cells known as Langerhans cells, which normally function to present antigens. The most frequent mutation associated with LCH is the BRAFV600E gain-of-function mutation.

LCH is characterized by single or multiple osteolytic bone lesions and can affect almost any organ, including the skin (particularly the scalp), lungs, liver, spleen, bone marrow, and central nervous system.

LCH can manifest in various clinical forms:

Multifocal multisystem LCH (Letterer-Siwe disease)

Unifocal and multifocal unisystem LCH (eosinophilic granuloma)

The Hand-Schüller-Christian triad, which includes bone defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos

Pulmonary LCH

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 627,628 .

questions.text: Identify the mode of inheritance from the pedigree chart given below.
questions.solution:
The pedigree chart shows an autosomal dominant mode of inheritance.
Autosomal dominant conditions are manifested in the heterozygous state, hence at least one parent of an index case is usually affected. In this mode of inheritance, both males and females are affected and both can transmit the condition. When an affected person marries an unaffected one, every child has one in two chance of having the disease.
 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 144 .

questions.text:
Match the following disorders with their genetic abnormalities.

Genetic abnormalities		 Disorders
1 Trinucleotide repeat a Patau syndrome
2 Trisomy 18 b Huntington chorea
3 Trisomy 13 c Sickle cell anemia
4 Hb beta chain d Edward syndrome (Glu to val)
questions.solution:
Huntington's disease (HD) is an autosomal dominant, progressive brain disorder characterized by involuntary movements, emotional disturbances, and cognitive decline. It is caused by the degeneration of neurons and gliosis in the caudate lobe, putamen, and globuspallidus. This condition arises due to an abnormal expansion of the CAG trinucleotide in the Huntington gene on chromosome 4.

Edward's syndrome, or Trisomy 18, results from the inheritance of an extra copy of chromosome 18, usually due to meiotic nondisjunction. Clinical manifestations include micrognathia, low-set ears, a prominent occiput, and rocker-bottom feet. Patients often exhibit marked hypertonia, such as clenched hands with overlapping fingers. Common complications include cardiac defects (ventricular septal defects, patent ductus arteriosus) and gastrointestinal anomalies (Meckel's diverticulum, malrotation). Prenatal ultrasound typically reveals fetal growth restriction.
Trisomy 13 leads to Patau syndrome, characterized by midline facial clefts (such as cleft lip or palate) and musculoskeletal abnormalities like polydactyly. Other phenotypic features include microcephaly, low-set ears, hypertelorism, and a broad nasal bridge.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a point mutation in the ?-globin gene, leading to the substitution of valine for glutamate. This mutation results in the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS). Factors that contribute to sickling include infection, dehydration, and acidosis. Clinically, the disease manifests with moderately severe hemolyticanemia, jaundice, and painful bone crises. Aplastic crises occur when parvovirus B19 infects red cell progenitors, temporarily halting erythropoiesis and causing a sudden worsening of anemia.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3375,3404,757-759 .

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presenting with 36 weeks of gestation, underwent a C-Section for placenta accreta spectrum. During the procedure, there was profuse bleeding and she was transfused blood according to the massive blood transfusion protocol. Which of the following is not seen after a massive blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia can occur following a massive blood transfusion, which is defined as transfusing 50% of a patient‘s total blood volume within 3 hours or more than 5-10 units of RBCs. The associated complications include:

1. Citrate toxicity


2. Hypothermia (due to rapid transfusion of blood stored at 4°C)


3. Hypocalcemia, presenting as circumoralparesthesia


4. Hyperkalemia (caused by RBC potassium leakage during prolonged storage or irradiation, which increases potassium levels)


5. Dilutional coagulopathy



To prevent these issues, it is recommended to use washed or plasma-reduced RBCs, limit storage to less than 7-10 days, and avoid using RBCs stored for more than 24 hours after irradiation. Treatment options include administering insulin, glucose, calcium gluconate, and furosemide.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 895 .

questions.text: Most specific indicator of alcohol-induced liver dysfunction is
questions.solution:
The most specific indicator of alcohol-induced liver dysfunction among the given options is gamma-glutamyltransferase (GGT). GGT is frequently used as a marker for excessive alcohol consumption in patients with alcoholic liver disease. Although present in various tissues such as the kidneys, pancreas, and liver, GGT is primarily derived from the liver and is often employed to assess hepatobiliary conditions. Chronic alcohol use induces hepatic microsomal GGT, leading to elevated levels in individuals with alcohol use disorder.

Laboratory findings in alcohol-induced liver dysfunction typically include:

AST (SGOT) and ALT (SGPT) levels not exceeding 400 IU/L.

An AST/ALT ratio greater than 1.5.

Serum bilirubin levels over 3 mg/dL.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2618 .

questions.text: Most common cause of adrenal incidentaloma is
questions.solution:
The most common cause of an adrenal incidentaloma is a non-functioning adenoma.

Incidentalomas are categorized into the following types:

Non-functional: The most common type.

Functional: May present with conditions such as Cushing‘s syndrome, pheochromocytoma, aldosteronoma, or cortisol-producing adenoma.

Secondary metastasis: Seen in 2% of patients, commonly from the breast, lung, or kidneys.


For patients without a confirmed diagnosis, specific tests are recommended to identify underlying hormonally active tumors. These tests include:

(a) A low-dose (1 mg) overnight dexamethasone suppression test to rule out subclinical Cushing‘s syndrome.

(b) A 24-hour urine collection to measure catecholamines, metanephrines, or vanillylmandelic acid (VMA), or testing plasma metanephrine levels to exclude pheochromocytoma.


(c) In hypertensive patients, assessing serum electrolytes, plasma aldosterone, and plasma renin levels to exclude aldosteronoma.

Management of incidentalomas:

Non-functional tumors:

Tumors smaller than 4 cm are managed conservatively, with MRI surveillance every 3-6 months.

For tumors larger than 4 cm, laparoscopic adrenalectomy is performed.


Functional tumors:

Hormonal assays are performed in suspected cases or in symptomatic patients. If the results are positive, the tumor is managed accordingly. If left untreated, functional tumors have a higher risk of malignancy, which increases fourfold if the tumor exceeds 4 cm.


Secondary metastasis:

Fine-needle aspiration and biopsy are performed. Before the biopsy, pheochromocytoma must be excluded to prevent precipitating a hypertensive crisis.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2976 .

questions.text: A patient on long-term hemodialysis due to renal failure is likely to develop which type of amyloidosis?
questions.solution:
Patients undergoing long-term hemodialysis for renal failure can develop amyloidosis due to the deposition of beta-2 microglobulin. Beta-2 microglobulin is a component of the MHC class I molecule and a normal serum protein. In the past, patients with chronic kidney disease retained this protein in their circulation because it could not be filtered through older dialysis membranes. This led to its deposition in the joints, muscles, tendons, and ligaments. One potential complication of this deposition is carpal tunnel syndrome. However, with the introduction of newer dialysis filters, this complication has become rare.


 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 260,262 .

questions.text: Given below is an electron microscopy image of a cell. Identify the cell.
questions.solution:
Hairy cell leukemia derives its name from the appearance of the leukemic cells, which exhibit fine, hair-like projections that are most easily identified under a phase-contrast microscope. This is a distinct B-cell neoplasm that primarily affects middle-aged men. The cells in hairy cell leukemia express standard B-cell markers such as CD-19 and CD-20, as well as specific markers like CD11c, CD25, CD103, and annexin A1.

In a peripheral blood smear, hairy cells typically show round or kidney-shaped (reniform) nuclei and a moderate amount of pale blue cytoplasm with thread-like or bleb-like extensions. In the bone marrow, these cells are often trapped within a network of reticulinfibers, making it difficult to aspirate, a condition known as a “dry tap.”

Patients often present with massive splenomegaly due to infiltration by leukemic cells. Pancytopenia, due to bone marrow involvement, is also common. Additionally, patients may have atypical monocytopenia, which increases their risk of atypical mycobacterial infections. These tumors respond well to chemotherapy and BRAF inhibitors, and the prognosis is excellent.


Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th Edition, Page no 595,603,604.605,641-643 .

choices.text: Decrease in IgG and increase in IgM
Inability of neutrophils to fight against infections

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate concerning the immunological abnormality observed with the absence of CD40 in B cells?
questions.solution:
The absence of CD40 in B cells leads to Hyper IgM syndrome, characterized by a decrease in IgG and an increase in IgM. This condition often arises from loss-of-function mutations in either CD40 or activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID), a DNA-editing enzyme essential for immunoglobulin class switching and affinity maturation in B cells.

CD40 deficiency disrupts class switching and the production of memory cells, while the B-cell response to antigens remains unaffected, resulting in elevated levels of IgM antibodies. Therefore, the syndrome is termed Hyper IgM syndrome.

Patients typically have normal or elevated IgM levels but lack IgA and IgE, with extremely low levels of IgG. Clinically, they experience recurrent pyogenic infections due to the insufficient opsonizing IgG antibodies and are particularly susceptible to pneumonia caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 244,245 .

questions.text:
Match the following:
Sl no Disease Characteristics
1 Silicosis a- Basal lobes are involved
2 Mesothelioma b- Malignant pleural effusion without mediastinal shift
3 Caplan syndrome c- Initially demonstrated in coal workers
4 Asbestosis d- Crazy paving pattern
questions.solution:
• Silicosis : Crazy paving pattern
  • Mesothelioma: Malignant pleural effusion without mediastinal shift
  • Caplan syndrome: Initially demonstrated in coal workers
  • Asbestosis: Basal lobes are involved


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th edition, Page no 539,2530 .

questions.text: A phlebotomist needs to collect samples from a patient for several tests. Which of the following blood collection sequences will avoid contaminating the samples due to the additives in the tubes?
questions.solution:
• The correct color sequence of the blood collection tube is light blue-> red-> lavender-> grey.
  • And/or arterial blood samples in a single patient.
 
  • The Clinical & Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) has recommended a color sequence for multiple collections of venous
 
  • Yellow, pink, and blue -> light Blue-> red- > green lavender -> grey.



Reference: WHO guidelines on Drawing blood: Best practices in Phlebotomy. URL: https://www.who.int/publications/i/item/9789241599221

questions.text:
The BRCA1 gene is associated with:
A. Repair of double-strand DNA breaks
B. Risk of development of ovarian cancer
C. Tumor suppressor gene
D. Mutation is seen in the subset of Fanconianemia
questions.solution:
The BRCA1 gene is associated with:

Repair of double-strand DNA breaks

Increased risk of ovarian cancer

Tumor suppression


Both BRCA1 and BRCA2 are tumor suppressor genes. Mutations in these genes are linked to a higher risk of breast cancer in women. They are crucial for repairing double-stranded DNA breaks. Women with BRCA1 mutations are also at an elevated risk for developing epithelial ovarian cancer, while men with BRCA1 mutations have a slightly increased risk of prostate cancer.

BRCA2 mutations are connected to a range of cancers, including those of the ovary, prostate, pancreas, bile ducts, stomach, melanocytes, and B lymphocytes. Additionally, some germline BRCA2 mutations can lead to Fanconianemia. Both BRCA proteins and Fanconianemia proteins work together within a DNA damage response network associated with homologous recombination repair. Deficiencies in this pathway may trigger nonhomologous end-joining mechanisms, potentially leading to telomere shortening.

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 124,292,281 .

questions.text: Identify the histopathological image
questions.solution:
The histopathological slide presented uses Congo red staining, which is employed to identify amyloid deposits.

Amyloidosis is characterized by the extracellular accumulation of fibrillar proteins. These abnormal fibrils result from the aggregation of misfolded proteins. The fibrillar deposits bind various proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, such as heparansulfate and dermatan sulfate, as well as plasma proteins like serum amyloid P component (SAP). Under a microscope, amyloid appears as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline extracellular substance.

Amyloidosis can be classified into systemic, localized, and hereditary types. Microscopically, all forms of amyloid deposits consist of continuous, nonbranching fibrils. A distinctive cross-?-pleated sheet conformation is detectable using X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy.

Congo red staining is used to visualize amyloid deposits, which appear pink to red under ordinary light and exhibit apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

The image displays a Congo-red stained biopsy specimen showing:

(A) Focal positive staining (orange-red) of amorphous extracellular material

(B) Apple-green birefringence under polarized light

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 259,260,547,768,848,849,993 .

questions.text: The most common genetic cause of hypercoagulability is:
questions.solution:
The Factor V Leiden mutation is the most prevalent genetic cause of hypercoagulability. Inherited hypercoagulability is commonly due to mutations in the factor V and prothrombin genes. Among these, the Factor V Leiden mutation is the most frequent, followed by the prothrombin G20210A mutation.

The Leiden mutation is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. It causes factor V to become resistant to cleavage and inactivation by protein C, disrupting an essential antithrombotic pathway.

Deficiencies in Protein C, Protein S, and antithrombin III are less common causes of primary hypercoagulability.

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 126,127 .

questions.text: Which of the following is not essential in the workup of a mosaic Turner syndrome?
questions.solution:
Anti-nuclear antibodies are not essential in the evaluation of mosaic Turner syndrome.
 
  • Turner syndrome is characterized by the presence of a deletion or non-functional X chromosome in females.
  • About 50% of individuals with Turner syndrome have monosomy X (45, XO), which means they only have one X chromosome.
  • The remaining 50% exhibit mosaicism (45, X with mosaicism), where the body contains a mix of cells—some with the usual two sex chromosomes and others with only one X chromosome.
  • This mosaic Turner syndrome arises from random events during early fetal development and is not inherited.



Reference: Shankar Kikkeri N, Nagalli S. Turner Syndrome. [Updated 2023 Aug 8]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK554621/

questions.text:
Which of the following are the features of necrosis?
A. Disrupted cell membrane
B. Induces inflammation
C. Swelling of the cell
D. Physiological
questions.solution:
The features of necrosis include:

Disrupted cell membrane

Induces inflammation

Swelling of the cell


Necrosis is characterized by the denaturation of cellular proteins, leakage of cellular contents through damaged membranes, local inflammation, and enzymatic digestion. It can result from loss of oxygen supply, exposure to microbial toxins, burns, and other forms of chemical or physical injury.

When the cell membrane is damaged, lysosomal enzymes enter the cytoplasm and digest the cell. The leaked cellular contents move into the extracellular space, causing inflammation.

Morphological changes in necrosis include:

Cell size: Increased

Cytoplasmic changes:

Increased eosinophilic staining on H&E specimens

Moth-eaten appearance due to vacuolated cytoplasmic organelles from enzymatic degradation

Glassy and homogeneous cytoplasm from loss of glycogen


Nuclear changes:

Pyknosis: The nucleus shrinks and becomes more condensed

Karyorrhexis: Fragmentation of the pyknotic nucleus

Karyolysis: The nucleus fades away, leaving behind only the cell membrane or empty cells


 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9th edition, Page no 42 .

questions.text: Thymus is designed to recognize the MHC molecules presented to it and distinguish the cells as self and foreign. Which gene is responsible for this?MHC :Major histocompatibility complex
questions.solution:
Central tolerance is a crucial process for eliminating self-reactive T and B lymphocytes during their development in central lymphoid organs—the thymus for T cells and the bone marrow for B cells. This process ensures that these self-reactive clones are either destroyed or rendered inactive.

In the thymus, self-reactive T lymphocytes are removed through a process known as negative selection or deletion, which requires the AIRE (Autoimmune Regulator) protein. Mutations in the AIRE gene can lead to autoimmune polyendocrinopathy.

For B cells, receptor editing is employed. When developing B cells encounter self-antigens, they undergo changes to alter their receptor so it no longer recognizes the self-antigen. Additionally, self-reactive B cells may be eliminated through apoptosis.

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 216,285,607,324 .

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-apoptotic factor?
questions.solution:
MCL1 is an anti-apoptotic factor among the options provided. Anti-apoptotic factors, such as BCL2, BCL-XL, and MCL1, are located in the outer mitochondrial membrane, cytosol, and endoplasmic reticulum membranes. They work by maintaining the impermeability of the mitochondrial outer membrane, thereby preventing the release of cytochrome c and other death-promoting proteins into the cytosol.

In contrast, pro-apoptotic factors like BAX and BAK, upon activation, form oligomers in the outer mitochondrial membrane, increasing its permeability. This leads to the leakage of death-promoting proteins into the cytosol.

Additionally, regulated apoptosis initiators include BAD, BIM, BID, Puma, and Noxa. These factors become active during cellular stress or damage and trigger the apoptosis process.

 

Reference: Robbins Basic Pathology, 10th edition, Page no 44,45 .

questions.text:
Which of the following are the true statements about amyloidosis?
A. It is an extracellular protein.
B. It is called amyloid because of starch deposition.
C. Beta-pleated sheets are seen on X-ray crystallography
D. AL is a secondary type of amyloidosis.
questions.solution:
Amyloidosis is characterized by the extracellular deposition of fibrillar proteins. These abnormal fibrils result from the aggregation of misfolded proteins and bind to a variety of proteoglycans and glycosaminoglycans, such as heparansulfate and dermatan sulfate, as well as plasma proteins, notably the serum amyloid P component (SAP). Under a microscope, amyloid deposits appear as an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline substance.

The term "amyloid" is derived from the deposits' resemblance to starch due to their staining characteristics, as they contain abundant charged sugar groups. This resemblance was the basis for the name "amyloid."

Amyloidosis can be classified into systemic, localized, or hereditary types. All types of amyloid deposits are composed of continuous, nonbranching fibrils with a characteristic ?-pleated sheet conformation, which can be visualized using X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy.

To identify amyloid deposits, the Congo red stain is used. This stain imparts a pink to red color under ordinary light and shows apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

The AL type of amyloidosis, also known as immunoglobulin light chain amyloidosis, is associated with primary amyloidosis and is often observed in multiple myeloma and other monoclonal plasma cell proliferations.

The biopsy specimen described in the image demonstrates Congo red staining with focal positive staining (orange-red) of amorphous extracellular material and apple-green birefringence under polarized light.

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 259,260,574,768,848,849,993 .

choices.text: Mode can be used as a qualitative data descriptor

questions.text: All of the following statements are true for descriptors of central tendency except:
questions.solution:
The mode is not influenced by extreme values in a data set.

The mean, however, is sensitive to every value in the distribution. Therefore, it is the measure of central tendency most affected by extreme values (option B). The mean is typically not appropriate for describing skewed distributions, but it tends to remain stable across repeated samples from the same population. Compared to the mode or median, the mean is less prone to fluctuations between different samples from the same population.

To find the median, the data must be arranged in ascending or descending order, and the middle value is selected. This process requires considering the entire data set before the median can be determined (option C).

The mode is the most frequently occurring value in a frequency distribution. It is not affected by extreme values and can also be used to describe qualitative data (option D).

 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page no 943 .

questions.text: The formula given in the image corresponds to-
questions.solution:
The formula given above is used to calculate the standard deviation.

Standard deviation (or o) is a measure of how dispersed the data is in relation to the mean. Data clustered around the mean have a low standard deviation, while data that are more spread out have a high standard deviation. A standard deviation close to zero indicates that data points are close to the mean, whereas a high or low standard deviation indicates data points are respectively above or below the mean.

Variance (option B) is the mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution. It is numerically equal to the square of the standard deviation.

Mean (option C) is obtained by adding together the individual observations and then dividing by the total number of observations.

Median (option D) divides the frequency distribution in half when all the scores are listed in order. When a distribution has an odd number of elements, the median is the middle value. When the distribution has an even number of elements, the median is the average of the two middle scores.


 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page no 943,944 .

questions.text: Which of the following is not correctly matched?
questions.solution:
The CONSORT (Consolidated Standards of Reporting Trials) guidelines are used for reporting the results of randomized controlled trials (RCTs). To enhance the quality of health research reporting, specific standards have been established based on the type of study conducted. Many journals now require authors to complete the appropriate checklist aligned with these standards before submitting their work for publication. 



Reference : Essential Edidemiology : An Introduction For Students and health Professionals, Page no 264,303 .

questions.text: All of the following may be used to find the normalcy of data except:
questions.solution:
The Mantel-Haenszel method is used to calculate the adjusted odds ratio during stratified analysis, not to assess the normalcy of data.

A histogram and a box whisker plot are visual tools to evaluate if a dataset follows a normal distribution. A normal distribution curve is a type of histogram.

However, visual representations alone may not be sufficient to determine normality. This is where the Shapiro-Wilk test comes into play. It assesses how closely a dataset fits a normal distribution. The test first orders and standardizes the sample data, then evaluates how the sample quantiles align with standard normal quantiles. The Shapiro-Wilk test is particularly useful for small sample sizes.

Stratified analysis is performed to minimize confounding. In such cases, multiple odds ratios are generated for each data stratum. These are then combined to produce an adjusted odds ratio, reflecting the exposure‘s effect after accounting for the confounding factor. The Mantel-Haenszel method is used to achieve this adjustment.



Reference : Essential Edidemiology : An Introduction For Students and health Professionals,  Page no 464,465 .

questions.text: In Kaplan Meier survival curve, the bands used for the confidence interval is?
questions.solution:
• The Hall-Wellner bands are used for confidence intervals in the Kaplan-Meier survival curve.
  • When employing standard statistical software, the upper and lower confidence interval limits are calculated at each time point.
  • Hall-Wellner bands, along with Gill bands and Nair‘s Equal Precision confidence bands, are commonly used for this purpose.
 
  • The Kaplan-Meier plot visually represents the number of individuals surviving over a specific time period. Typically, the plot displays two or more groups, such as treated versus untreated individuals.
  • The graph consists of steps, as survival is a discrete variable. The image below illustrates a Kaplan-Meier plot, with dotted lines indicating the upper and lower bounds of the 95% confidence interval



Reference: Sachs, M.C., Brand, A. & Gabriel, E.E. Confidence bands in survival analysis. Br J Cancer 127, 1636–1641 (2022). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41416-022-01920-5. URL: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41416-022-01920-5

questions.text: A group of 30,000 women was observed over 10 years to monitor the development of breast cancer. Among them, 1,200 women who developed breast cancer were given a questionnaire to evaluate potential risk factors. Additionally, 2,000 women from the same cohort who did not develop breast cancer were selected as controls and were also administered the questionnaire. What is the classification of this type of study?
questions.solution:
• A nested case-control study is a type of case-control study conducted within a cohort study.
 
  • In this design, the cases consist of cohort members who developed the disease under investigation at a specific point during the follow-up period. Each case is paired with one or more controls — individuals who did not develop the disease but are otherwise similar to the cases in terms of age and gender.
 
  • The exposures of both cases and controls to the risk factor are then compared. Essentially, nested case-control studies provide an interim analysis of the exposure and outcome data within a cohort study.


 

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th edition, Page no 84, 85.

questions.text: A person had a dog bite. Vaccination is up to date for both the dog and the man. The person‘s history is significant for having undergone splenectomy five years ago. What is the best management in this case?
questions.solution:
• Amoxicillin-clavulanate (Amoxiclav) is the preferred antibiotic for this patient.

Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended in the following cases:
 
  • High-risk animal bites: This includes cat bites at any location and bites to the hand from any animal, including humans. Cat and human bites have a higher risk of infection compared to dog bites. Hand bites, in particular, are prone to infections due to the closed spaces within the hand.
 
  • High-risk patients: Individuals with comorbidities such as diabetes, liver disease, or asplenia (lack of a functional spleen) are at greater risk. Those without a functional spleen are especially vulnerable to overwhelming sepsis, particularly from Capnocytophaga species.
 
  • Pasteurella species is the most common pathogen found in cat and dog bites while Streptococci, Staphylococcus aureus and Eikenella corrodens are typically associated with human bites. Amoxicillin-clavulanate is the first-line treatment for prophylaxis. For patients allergic to penicillin, alternative regimens include clindamycin combined with doxycycline, cotrimoxazole, or a fluoroquinolone.



Reference: Current Medical Diagnosis & Treatment 2023, Page no 1283,1284 .

questions.text: A child arrived for a DPT vaccination at 10 weeks of age. At 6 weeks, following a previous vaccination, the child experienced a fever over 40°C and an inconsolable cry. What is the appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
The appropriate next step for this patient is to administer the DPT vaccine.
 
  • Events such as prolonged inconsolable crying (lasting more than 3 hours), high fever (hyperpyrexia > 40°C), hypotonic-hyporesponsive episodes within 48 hours of DTwP administration, and seizures, with or without fever, within 72 hours of DTwP administration are considered precautions, not contraindications, for future DTwP doses.
  • These events typically do not recur with subsequent doses and have not been associated with any long-term complications.
 
  • Absolute contraindications to pertussis vaccination include a history of anaphylaxis or the development of encephalopathy within 7 days after a previous DTwP vaccination.
  • In cases of anaphylaxis, further immunization with diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis vaccines is contraindicated, as it is unclear which component triggered the reaction.
  • For patients who have experienced encephalopathy following vaccination, any pertussis-containing vaccine is contraindicated, and only diphtheria and tetanus vaccines should be given.



Reference: IAP Guidebook on Immunisation 2018-19, Page no 136-142.

questions.text:
Which among the following is true about keto diet ?
A. Diet should contain 800 kcal from fat
B. Diet should contain 400 kcal from carbohydrates
C. Diet should contain 80% fats
D. Diet should contain total 1000 kcal
questions.solution:
According to the FDA, a high-fat diet or keto diet should provide a total of 1000 kcal. These diets are characterized by low carbohydrate intake, less than 50 grams per day, which equates to less than 250 kcal from carbohydrates, not 400 kcal (as mentioned in option B). More than 50% of the calories should come from fats (option C), translating to around 500-600 kcal from fats (option A). The total caloric intake should range between 800 and 1000 kcal.

Ketogenic diets, which are low in carbohydrates (under 50 grams/day), low in protein, and high in fats, rely on fat oxidation and gluconeogenesis from glucogenic amino acids to fulfill the body‘s energy requirements. These diets are particularly effective in managing intractable epilepsy.


 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd edition, Page no 146 .

choices.text: Tell sequence of events in detail after the bite

questions.text: Which among the following is false regarding management of snake bite ?
questions.solution:
-Incisions are not part of managing a snake bite. The first aid for a snake bite can be remembered using the mnemonic “carry no right”:

Carry: The victim should not walk, as movement increases muscle activity, which can spread the venom throughout the body.

No: Avoid using a tourniquet, electrotherapy, cutting, pressure immobilization, or suction at the bite site.

R: Reassure the patient, as 70% of snake bites come from non-venomous species.

I: Immobilize the affected limb similar to a fractured limb, using a splint to limit movement and keep it in a neutral position at heart level.

GH: Get the victim to a hospital immediately. Rapid transport to a medical facility with the capability to provide appropriate care is crucial.

T: Inform the doctor of any systemic symptoms that have developed while en route to the hospital.


Note that for envenomations from elapid snakes, which are mainly neurotoxic with minimal local tissue effects, pressure immobilization may be used. This involves wrapping the entire limb with a bandage to limit lymphatic drainage and delay venom absorption. However, this technique should only be applied if the snake has been identified as neurotoxic and the rescuer is trained in the procedure.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3597,3598 .

questions.text:
Calculate the Kappa statistics for the following data comparing IGRA and Mantoux test. 

The table provided is as follows:
IGRA (+) IGRA (-) Total
Mantoux (+) 80 40 120
Mantoux (-) 20 60 80
100 100 200
questions.solution:
Kappa statistic is used to evaluate the agreement between IGRA and TST test results.
It is calculated as given in the image.



Reference: McHugh, Mary L. “Interrater reliability: the kappa statistic.” Biochemia medica vol. 22,3 (2012): 276-82. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3900052/

questions.text: Identify the following image.
questions.solution:
The image of burns with blisters and surrounding hyperemia suggests a diagnosis of antemortem burns.

In antemortem burns, a zone of hyperemia (a line of redness) is present at the edge of the burn area. This hyperemia, which varies in width, is due to tissue edema and capillary dilation, merging with the burn‘s edge. It affects the full thickness of the skin and persists even after death. If the entire body is burned, this line of redness will be absent.

Antemortem blisters appear as raised domes containing serous fluid with proteins and chlorides. The base of these blisters shows reddening and swollen papillae. In cases of antemortem burns, the skin adjacent to the burn area exhibits increased enzyme activity. This includes elevated levels of sulfhydryl groups in all skin layers, as well as increases in ATP esterases, aminopeptidases, and both acid and alkaline phosphatases. These changes, along with marked cellular exudation and reactive tissue changes, are known as vital reactions and are characteristic of antemortem burns.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 326,327,588,589 .

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy visited a village temple with his grandmother. On the way back, he cried inconsolably and was taken to the emergency department within 3 hours. He presented with altered sensorium, cold clammy extremities, increased salivation, and excessive sweating. Examination revealed pallor and priapism, with the following vital signs: BP 140/78 mmHg, HR 152/min, RR 36/min, and SpO2 96%. Which of the following treatments would be appropriate for his condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation suggests a likely diagnosis of a scorpion bite, for which Prazosin can be used in management. Prazosin serves as a physiological antidote, counteracting the symptoms of adrenergic surge.

Scorpion venom is a potent autonomic stimulator that induces the release of large amounts of catecholamines from the adrenal glands and directly affects the myocardium. Typically, a scorpion sting presents with localized redness, burning pain that radiates along the involved dermatomes, localized swelling, and punctate hemorrhagic spots. Additional symptoms may include headache, profuse sweating, chest discomfort, paraesthesias, hypersalivation, cold extremities, and occasionally priapism. Hypertension often occurs early, while pulmonary edema and myocarditis may develop later.

Treatment includes:

Pain Management: Paracetamol, NSAIDs, or opioids.

Sedation: Benzodiazepines for agitation, oculomotor abnormalities, uncoordinated neuromuscular activity, and muscle spasms.

Hypertension and Pulmonary Edema: Prazosin helps counteract the adrenergic surge associated with these effects.

Cardiogenic Shock: Antivenom, Prazosin, nitroglycerin, and dobutamine.

Cholinergic Effects: Atropine.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 556 .

choices.text: He has consumed alcohol but is not under its influence
He has consumed alcohol and is under the influence of alcohol

questions.text: In an examination for drunkenness, a person smells of alcohol and has red conjunctiva. During the motor coordination assessment, it is observed that he can walk in a straight line and speak normally. Which of the following statements is accurate?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario where a person smells of alcohol but has normal motor coordination and no slurred speech, it suggests that the person has consumed alcohol but is not currently affected by it.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 579,580 .

questions.text: The Blackfoot disease is an endemic peripheral vascular disease seen in toxicity of which of the following metal?
questions.solution:
Blackfoot disease results from chronic arsenic poisoning. In Taiwan, China, exposure to arsenic through drinking water has been linked to a severe vascular condition that causes gangrene, known as Blackfoot disease. This disease is characterized by platelet activation and increased blood coagulability in peripheral arteries and is commonly seen in regions with high arsenic levels.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 538-540,549 .

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl, accompanied by her mother and a lady police sub-inspector, presents with a reported history of sexual violence 2 days prior. What should the registered medical practitioner do next?
questions.solution:
The registered medical practitioner should first take a detailed history and obtain informed consent for the examination. If consent is refused, the refusal must be documented after explaining the potential consequences. Following consent, the practitioner should collect specimens, preserve clothing, and document injuries and examination findings. Medical treatment and pregnancy testing for victims of sexual assault must be provided free of charge, and the police should be notified as required by Section 357C of the CrPC.

The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 defines individuals under 18 years of age as children and offers protection from sexual abuse. The Act outlines various forms of sexual offenses, including:

Sexual Harassment: This occurs when a person, with sexual intent, engages in any act with sexual connotations, makes a child display their body, or shows pornographic material to a child.

Sexual Assault: Involves any act with sexual intent that entails physical contact without penetration.

Aggravated Sexual Assault: Similar to sexual assault but includes additional criteria defined as “aggravated.”

Penetrative Sexual Assault: Involves an act with sexual intent that includes physical penetration.

Aggravated Penetrative Sexual Assault: Similar to penetrative sexual assault but includes additional “aggravated” criteria.


Aggravated offenses involve situations such as:

Committed by a person in a position of trust or authority, such as police officers, security forces, relatives, or doctors.

Occurring during communal violence.

Involving mentally or physically disabled individuals.

Gang sexual assault.

Utilizing deadly weapons.

Causing grievous harm.


The Act prescribes severe penalties, including life imprisonment and fines, based on the severity of the offense. Section 21(1) of the POCSO Act, 2012 mandates the reporting of child sexual abuse cases to law enforcement authorities by everyone, including parents, doctors, and school personnel. Failing to report suspected child abuse is an offense under the Act.

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 35th edition, Page no 330,331 .

choices.text: Cadaveric spasm is observed only in specific groups of muscles
Greenish discoloration in the right iliac fossa is the earliest sign of decomposition
Adipocere is found in bodies recovered from water sources
In drowning cases, postmortem hypostasis is only seen in the lower limbs

questions.text: Which of the following statements about postmortem changes is incorrect?
questions.solution:
In drowning cases, if the water is still, post-mortem hypostasis affects the head, chest, and limbs. This occurs because the chest and abdomen float higher due to the presence of lung and abdominal gases. However, in drowning incidents in fast-flowing water, postmortem staining may be absent since the body's position continuously changes.

Postmortem hypostasis (also known as postmortem staining, postmortemlividity, livor mortis, or suggilation) refers to the bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the dermis. This early postmortem change results from blood pooling in the dependent areas due to gravity.


 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 152,155-158,163,165,171 .

choices.text: White leathery foam around the mouth and nostrils

questions.text: A female was brought in for an autopsy with a reported history of being discovered at a village lake. Which of the following findings is NOT indicative of antemortem drowning?
questions.solution:
Antemortem Drowning Features:

External Features:

Froth: The most distinctive sign of antemortem drowning is the presence of abundant, fine, shaving-lather-like froth around the mouth and nostrils. This froth results from the agitation of tracheal and bronchial mucus, edema fluid, and alveolar surfactant during breathing efforts.

Cutis Anserina: This term describes the pucker and grainy appearance of the skin due to the contraction of the erector pili muscles, resembling goose skin.

Washerwoman‘s Hands and Feet: This refers to the wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance of the skin on the palms and soles due to maceration from submersion in water. It can be seen in both antemortem and postmortem drowning cases.

Cadaveric Spasm: In cases of antemortem drowning, gravel, weeds, soil, and other materials may be firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This finding helps to indicate the location of the drowning.

Rigor Mortis: This appears early in cases involving a violent struggle before death.

Facial Appearance: The face may be bloated and discolored with cyanosis.

Eyes: The conjunctiva are often suffused, and the pupils may be dilated.

Tongue: It might be swollen and protruded.

Antemortem Injuries: These may result from striking objects, such as rocks, during the fall into the water. These injuries should be examined only after the body is dry.


Internal Findings:

Lungs: They appear voluminous and distended, often showing ballooning. A cut section of the lungs will exude copious amounts of frothy, bloodstained fluid.

Larynx, Trachea, and Bronchioles: The presence of sand, silt, and aquatic vegetation in these areas is characteristic of antemortem drowning.

Heart and Blood Vessels: The Gettler test can be conducted to measure the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart, helping to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

Diatom Test: Diatoms, microscopic algae, can be found in the organs, especially in the bone marrow, and their presence suggests antemortem drowning.

Stomach and Small Intestines: These organs may contain water, with water in the small intestine being positive evidence of drowning.

Middle Ear: Water present in the middle ear is highly indicative of antemortem drowning.

Brain: The brain is typically congested, edematous, and may show loss of the gray-white matter junction.


Reference: Review Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology Including Clinical And Pathological Aspects, Page no 179-182 .

questions.text: In cases of firearm-related death where the entry wound exhibits only an abrasion collar, the range of the firearm is:
questions.solution:
When the entry wound displays only an abrasion collar, it indicates that the firearm was discharged from a distant range.

To determine the firing range, the following parameters are considered:

The size and shape of the entry wound

Blast effects, including muzzle end imprint and edge eversion

Blackening, tattooing, singeing of hair, abrasion collar, and grease collar

Hair should be preserved for analysis, as it can reveal carbonization or desiccation at close range. Additionally, lead deposition around the wound can help assess the firing range

 

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 33rd edition, Page no 224 .

questions.text: The vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) helps to keep the image stable on the retina during head movements. What is the gain of the VOR (eye velocity/head velocity)?
questions.solution:
The gain of the vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR) is 1, indicating that the eye velocity matches the head velocity but in the opposite direction.

The VOR maintains stable retinal images during head movements by causing the eyes to move at the same speed but in the opposite direction of the head. When tracking an object with both eye and head movements, the VOR is suppressed to prevent the eyes from moving contrary to the head.

The VOR is a type of physiological vestibular nystagmus and serves as the basis for the caloric test. When cold water is introduced into the right ear, the patient exhibits left jerk nystagmus (with the rapid phase directed to the left). Conversely, warm water causes right jerk nystagmus (with the rapid phase directed to the right). This can be remembered using the mnemonic ‘COWS‘ (Cold Opposite, Warm Same).


 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 354,374 .

questions.text: In ocular surface examination and dry eye staining, which sequence of dyes is applied?
questions.solution:
#controversial 

The correct answer is: 2. Fluorescein → Lissamine Green → Rose Bengal  (NOTE: #controversial - answer given as 4 in certain "Qbanks" - however, we have confirmed with faculty of AIIMS, Delhi that the sequence F-L-R is correct)

Explanation for the sequence

1.Fluorescein: Stains areas of epithelial damage. Highlights corneal abrasions, punctate epithelial erosions, and epithelial defects.Applied first because it does not interfere with the uptake of the other dyes.

2. Lissamine Green: Stains damaged and devitalized epithelial cells and mucin-deficient areas. More comfortable than Rose Bengal (less irritation). Used after fluorescein to enhance detection of conjunctival surface damage.



3. Rose Bengal: Stains devitalized and dead epithelial cells as well as mucin-deficient areas. Causes more irritation and discomfort compared to Lissamine Green. Used last to avoid interference from other stains.




Reference  Srinivas SP, Rao SK. Ocular surface staining: Current concepts and techniques. Indian J Ophthalmol. 2023 Apr;71(4):1080-1089. doi: 10.4103/ijo.IJO_2137_22. PMID: 37026238; PMCID: PMC10276680.

questions.text:
Which of the following are direct gonioscopes?
A. Goldmann
B. Richardson
C. Zeis
D. Koeppe
questions.solution:
Richardson and Koeppe are examples of direct gonioscopes.

A gonioscope is used to measure the angle of the anterior chamber in the eye. Gonioscopes can be categorized as follows:

Indirect gonioprism: Provides a mirror image of the opposite angle. Examples include the Goldmann, Zeiss, and Posner gonioscopes.

Direct gonioprism: Offers a direct view of the angle. Examples include the Koeppe, Richardson, Medical Workshop, Barkan, and Swan-Jacob gonioscopes.


Applications of gonioscopy include:

Viewing the angle of the anterior chamber, where structures are observed in the following order from front to back:

Schwalbe‘s line

Trabecular meshwork

Scleral spur

Ciliary body band

Root of iris


Identifying foreign bodies, abnormal blood vessels, or tumors in the angle.

Assessing the extent of peripheral anterior synechiae.

Performing goniotomy, a surgical procedure for treating congenital glaucoma.


Reference: Parson’s Diseases of the Eye, 23rd Edition, Page no 110,116 .

questions.text: On administration of phenylephrine, the following change was noted as shown in the images below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows a nodule with surrounding redness. Upon administering phenylephrine, blanching of the superficial episcleral vessels is observed, suggesting the diagnosis of nodular episcleritis.

Phenylephrine 2.5% is used to distinguish between episcleritis and scleritis. The episcleral vessels, being superficial, will blanch with phenylephrine, whereas the vessels in scleritis will not.

Episcleritis is a benign, recurrent inflammation of the episclera and the overlying Tenon‘s capsule, but not the deeper sclera. It is more common in women and often associated with rheumatoid arthritis. This condition is characterized by redness, mild ocular discomfort, and a sensation described as gritty, burning, or like a foreign body.

Episcleritis can present in two forms:

1. Simple Episcleritis: Features sectorial or diffuse inflammation of the episclera.


2. Nodular Episcleritis: Exhibits a pink or purple flat nodule with surrounding redness, typically located 2-3 mm from the limbus. The nodule is firm, tender, and can be moved separately from the sclera, while the overlying conjunctiva moves freely.



Treatment includes topical NSAIDs, corticosteroid eye drops, cold compresses, and artificial tears. For recurrent cases, systemic NSAIDs may be used.

Scleritis involves inflammation of the sclera itself, commonly affecting individuals aged 40-70 years, with a higher prevalence in women. It is frequently linked to underlying systemic inflammatory conditions and is characterized by moderate to severe pain, redness, lacrimation, photophobia, and reduced vision.

Scleritis is classified into immune-mediated non-infectious and infectious types:

1. Immune-Mediated Non-Infectious Scleritis:

Anterior Scleritis (98% of cases):

Non-Necrotizing Scleritis (85%): Includes diffuse and nodular types.

Necrotizing Scleritis (13%):

With inflammation: Vasa-occlusive, granulomatous, surgically induced.

Without inflammation: Scleromalaciaperforans.



Posterior Scleritis (2%).



2. Infectious Scleritis.



Treatment varies based on the type of scleritis:

Non-Necrotizing Scleritis: Treated with topical steroids and systemic indomethacin.

Necrotizing Scleritis: Requires topical and oral steroids, immunosuppressive agents, and possibly surgical interventions like scleral patch grafts.

Infectious Scleritis: Managed with antimicrobial therapy and, if necessary, surgical debridement.

 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 146-149 .

questions.text: identify the marked structure in the eye?
questions.solution:
The marked structure represend the canal of petit
Located in front of the anterior hyaloid membrane and behind the ciliary body and zonule, the capsulohyaloid sinus (or Petit‘s canal) is a notable area for retrolentalhemorrhages. It is also a pathway through which blood can enter the lens, often following a rupture in the posterior lens capsule.
 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 184 .

choices.text: In Static perimetry, stimulus intensity is held constant and moved centrally with detection.
Visual field defect to be classified as glaucoma, it should have the corresponding optic nerve head abnormalities
Early signs include generalised constriction of isopters and barring of blind spot.
Kinetic perimetry is used in quantification and tracking of visual changes in established glaucoma

questions.text: which of the following is true about perimetry?
questions.solution:
Perimetry involves assessing the extent of visual fields and comes in two types: kinetic and static. In kinetic perimetry, a target with a specific luminance is moved from an area where it is not seen toward the center until it is detected by the subject. In static perimetry, the stimulus remains in a fixed location, and its intensity is adjusted until the subject either sees it (indicating the threshold is reached) or no longer detects it.

Charting visual fields is valuable for diagnosing various conditions, including glaucoma, neurological disorders, and retinal diseases like retinitis pigmentosa, as well as for monitoring the effects of laser treatment for diabetic retinopathy.

 

Reference: Comprehensive Ophthalmology by AK Khurana, 7th edition, Page no 246,533-534 .

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with gradual swelling on the left side of his face for the past two weeks. He has a history of a wood injury two months ago. A CECT of the nose and paranasal sinuses reveals a mass in the subcutaneous tissue of the left cheek. A biopsy of the specimen shows a foreign body granuloma with positive PAS and GMS stains. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described strongly suggests mucormycosis (phycomycosis). A positive fungal stain, specifically Grocott-Gomori‘smethenamine silver (GMS) stain, supports this diagnosis. Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungal infection caused by molds in the order Mucorales, which include the genera Rhizopus, Mucor, and Absidia. These fungi are ubiquitous and thermotolerant, commonly found in air and dust.

In immunocompetent individuals, mucormycosis can manifest as isolated cutaneous or subcutaneous infections following trauma with soil or vegetation. The disease is highly invasive, often penetrating into muscle, fascia, and bone due to the fungi‘s angio-invasive properties. Although the lungs are typically the primary site of infection, rhinocerebralmucormycosis is common in individuals with diabetic ketoacidosis. This form begins with eye and facial pain, progressing to orbital cellulitis, proptosis, and potential vision loss, with a characteristic black necrotic mass in the nasal cavity.

Diagnosis involves:

Exudate Examination: A wet preparation in 10% potassium hydroxide reveals broad, ribbon-like hyphae.

Tissue Analysis: Hematoxylin and eosin staining shows broad, non-septate hyphae, often invading blood vessels. Special stains can identify the fungus in tissue sections.

Biopsy: Confirms the diagnosis by showing non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching, typical of Mucorales like Rhizopusdelemar. These hyphae are broad (10-15 µm), uneven in thickness, irregularly branched, and sparsely septate.

Culture: Isolation on Sabouraud agar (with antibacterial agents but without cycloheximide) yields grey-white colonies with a thick, cottony surface.


Treatment involves primarily liposomal amphotericin B and is complemented by surgical debridement of affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing conditions.

 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no 229-230 .

questions.text: <strong>Arrange the following structures in the hearing pathway from the receptors to the cortex
questions.solution:
The auditory pathway progresses as follows: spiral ganglion, cochlear nucleus, olivary complex, lateral lemniscus, inferior colliculus, medial geniculate body, and auditory cortex.

The spiral ganglion, located in Rosenthal's canal, houses bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells converge to create the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve, which terminates in the cochlear nuclei.

 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no 17 .

questions.text: Identify the nerve block shown in the image
questions.solution:
The nasociliary nerve block is performed by inserting the needle approximately 1 cm superior and 1.5 cm posterolateral to the medial canthal ligament of the eye. The nasociliary nerve is a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, which itself is a branch of the trigeminal nerve.

Branches of the nasociliary nerve include:
  1. Long ciliary nerves: Provide sensory innervation to the cornea, ciliary body, and iris.
  2. Ramus communicans to the ciliary ganglion: Contributes to the sensory functions of the eye.
  3. Posterior ethmoidal nerve: Supplies sensory innervation to the frontal sinus and the posterior ethmoidal air cells.
  4. Anterior ethmoidal nerve: Provides sensory innervation to the middle and anterior ethmoidal cells and the lateral part of the nasal septum.
  5. Infratrochlear nerve: A continuation of the nasociliary nerve that innervates the conjunctiva, lacrimal sac, caruncle, and the medial part of the eyelids.


The nasociliary nerve block is used in various procedures, including:
 
  • Surgery for nasal fractures
  • Septoplasty
  • Rhinoplasty
  • Repair of skin lacerations



Reference: Miller's anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 2412-2414.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway:
A. Cochlear nucleus
B. Spiral ganglion
C. Superior olivary nucleus
D. Inferior colliculus
E. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans-
Ans-The auditory pathway follows this sequence: spiral ganglion (2) - cochlear nucleus (1) - superior olivary nucleus (3) - inferior colliculus (4) - medial geniculate body (5).

The spiral ganglion houses bipolar cells, with their dendrites providing the afferent input from the inner and outer hair cells of the organ of Corti. These cells' axons form the cochlear division of cranial nerve VIII, which terminates in the cochlear nuclei.

To remember the auditory pathway, use the mnemonic ECOLIMA:

Eighth nerve

Cochlear nuclei

Olivary complex

Lateral lemniscus

Inferior colliculus

Medial geniculate body

Auditory cortex

 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no 16,17 .

questions.text: A 14-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with the issue of hearing speech sounds but struggling to comprehend the words. Her Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA) results are fairly normal, but the Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) results are inconsistent with PTA, showing absent middle latency and cortical responses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a clinical scenario involving a child who has difficulty understanding words and presents with abnormal Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry (BERA) while having normal Pure Tone Audiometry (PTA), auditory neuropathy should be considered.

Auditory neuropathy, or auditory dyssynchrony, is a disorder that impairs the neural processing of sound. The condition is characterized by:

Injury to the synaptic junction between the inner hair cells of the cochlea and the dendrites of the spiral ganglion neurons

Direct damage to the dendrites of the spiral ganglion neurons

Direct injury to the spiral ganglion neurons

Direct axonal damage to the auditory nerve


It is crucial to suspect auditory neuropathy in children who exhibit severe speech and language delays disproportionate to their perceived level of hearing loss.

For a diagnosis of auditory neuropathy in newborns, the following criteria must be met:

Absent or severely abnormal Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR) test results at maximal stimulus levels (100 dBnHL)

Normal outer hair cell function as determined by Otoacoustic Emissions (OAEs)

Absent or elevated stapedial reflex thresholds


In adults with mildly to moderately abnormal pure tone thresholds and disproportionate speech discrimination scores, further evaluation is necessary. Audiograms may show normal or slightly elevated pure tone thresholds.

Management typically involves conventional hearing aids. If a child does not show progress with hearing aids and has limited speech discrimination, cochlear implantation is considered the next option.

 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no43-44,103-106,135 .

questions.text: A South Indian male cattle breeder presents with intermittent, severe nosebleeds. An examination of the nose was conducted, and a biopsy was performed, with histopathological examination revealing specific findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical image depicting a polyp, along with histopathological findings showing numerous sporangia, suggests rhinosporidiosis.

 

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery by P.L Dhingra, 8th edition, Page no 185-186 .

questions.text: A patient who is under general anaesthesia shows the following finding on the ET CO2 monitor. Which condition can lead to this characteristic waveform on capnography?
questions.solution:
The above capnographic waveform depicts bronchospasm.

Shark fin appearance - Prolonged phase Il, increased a angle, and steeper phase II| suggest bronchospasm or airway obstruction.



Reference: Miller’s Anaesthesia, 9th Edition, Page no 1311 .

questions.text: In a patient with thrombocytopenia, platelet transfusion is done when the platelet level drops below a threshold. To proceed with surgery, platelet transfusion is done to achieve a platelet level of?
questions.solution:
• For most surgical procedures, a platelet count of at least 50,000/microL is considered adequate to reduce the risk of bleeding.
 
  • However, for more invasive or high-risk surgeries (e.g., neurosurgery or eye surgery), a higher platelet threshold, such as 100,000/microL, may be required.
 
  • For minor procedures or central line placement, a lower threshold (e.g., 20,000–30,000/microL) might suffice if there is no significant risk of bleeding.



Reference: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 963, 964, 967, 968 .

questions.text:
The presence of which of the following indicates that CPR is of high quality?
A. Chest compression at a rate of 100-120/minute
B. Breathing rate of 20-25/minute
C. Depth of compression should be 5-6 cm
D. Allow chest recoil
questions.solution:
High-quality CPR is indicated by performing chest compressions at a rate of 100-120 per minute, with a depth of 5-6 cm, and allowing for full chest recoil. When there is no advanced airway in place, the compression-to-ventilation ratio should be 30:2, meaning 30 compressions followed by 2 breaths. If an advanced airway, such as an endotracheal tube or supraglottic airway device, is present, provide 10 breaths per minute.


Reference : Basic Life Support Provider Mannual, Page no 10 .

questions.text: A 70 kg patient with acute pancreatitis was admitted to the ICU and intubated. The current ventilatory settings are: FiO2 90%, PEEP 12 mmHg, respiratory rate 16/min, and tidal volume 420 ml. The ABG analysis results are as follows:pH: 7.33, PaO2: 110 mmHg, PaCO2: 58 mmHg, SpO2: 100%. What should be the next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
Given the ABG and ventilatory settings, the patient has a mild respiratory acidosis (pH 7.33, PaCO 58 mmHg), but their oxygenation (PaO 110 mmHg, SpO 100%) is adequate, especially considering the high FiO (90%). Prolonged exposure to such a high FiO can lead to oxygen toxicity, so reducing FiO is the safest initial step if oxygenation remains stable.

Recommended next step: 3. Reduce FiO

Reducing FiO gradually to the lowest level that maintains adequate oxygenation (SpO > 88%) is advisable. This can help reduce potential oxygen toxicity while maintaining adequate oxygenation.

 

  • The primary treatment approach shown to reduce mortality in patients with ARDS is low tidal volume ventilation (6 mL/kg of predicted body weight). Increasing the tidal volume (option 1) in this patient could lead to barotrauma, as increased airflow can damage already collapsed alveoli.
 
  • Although high PEEP helps keep alveoli open, there’s no need to increase PEEP further (option 2) in this case, as oxygenation is already adequate. PEEP should be optimized to allow for the lowest FiO necessary to maintain adequate PaO.
 
  • Hypercapnia is expected in low tidal volume ventilation and can be managed by increasing the respiratory rate. Patients typically tolerate respiratory acidosis up to a pH of 7.2—known as permissive hypercapnia. Reducing the respiratory rate (option 4) would increase PaCO and worsen respiratory acidosis.
 
  • Other approaches, like prone positioning, early neuromuscular blockade (to prevent ventilator dys-synchrony), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO), have also shown mortality benefits in ARDS. In contrast, interventions like glucocorticoids and surfactant replacement have not been shown to improve outcomes in ARDS.
 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2227-2229, 2233.

questions.text: A 24 year old young male presented with asymptomatic scaly lesions over back, symmetrical in distribution. Images of the lesions are given, Identify the disease and the pattern of lesions
questions.solution:
The description provided, which includes central detachment and peripheral attachment of scales with images suggestive of collarette scales and a Christmas tree pattern, indicates pityriasisrosea. This condition, also known as pityriasiscircinata or roseolaannulata, is an acute, self-limiting papulosquamous disorder frequently observed in children and young adults.

Clinical features of pityriasisrosea include:

A prodrome characterized by sore throat, gastrointestinal disturbances, fever, or arthralgia.

Herald patch: A large, prominent lesion typically found on the thigh, upper arm, trunk, or neck, covered by fine scales.


Reference : Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no 115.9,35.8,37.3 .

choices.text: Statement 1 is true and Statement 2 is false
Statement 1 is false and Statement 2 is true
Both statements are true, and Statement 2 is the conclusion of Statement 1
Both statements are true, but Statement 2 is not the conclusion of Statement 1

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is correct?
Statement 1: Histopathological examination of a patient with flaccid bullae and painful erosions reveals a suprabasal blister with inflammatory infiltrate in the blister cleft.
Statement 2: A row of tombstones appearance is characteristic of Pemphigus vulgaris.
questions.solution:
Both statements 1 and 2 are correct; however, statement 2 is not derived as the conclusion of statement 1. This is because a definitive diagnosis of Pemphigus vulgaris requires direct immunofluorescence (DIF).

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is a chronic autoimmune blistering disorder caused by antibodies targeting desmosomal proteins in the skin and mucosa.
  • In the skin, desmoglein 1 is predominantly expressed in all layers, while desmoglein 3 is more concentrated in the lower layers. Conversely, in the oral mucosa, desmoglein 3 is expressed throughout all layers, and desmoglein 1 is present in the lower layers.
 
  • Clinically, patients present with irregular, slow-healing oral lesions and erosions.
  • Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid may form on normal or erythematous skin.
  • These blisters rupture easily, leading to painful erosions that heal without scarring. The disease can also affect other mucosal sites, including the conjunctiva, nasopharynx, larynx, esophagus, urethra, vulva, and cervix.
 
  • Nikolsky's sign is typically positive, elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure on affected or surrounding skin.
  • This pressure causes separation of the epidermis, forming erosions.

Supra-basal split:



Row of tombstone appearance:




Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 50.1-50.5 .

questions.text: Identify the following lines in dermatology
questions.solution:
The above image shows Blaschko lines as identified by the spiraling over the scalp. Blaschko‘s lines are lines of normal developmental growth patterns in the skin. They do not correspond to any known nervous, vascular, or lymphatic structures. Conditions that are distributed along these lines include epidermal nevi, and incontinentiapigmenti.



Reference : Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no 7.7,20.1 .

questions.text:
Match the following Wood's lamp findings with the disease:
 
Column I Column II
1 Erythrasma a Yellow fluorescence
2 Pityriasis versicolor b Milky white fluorescence
3 Tinea capitis c Pink fluorescence
4 Vitiligo d Blue fluorescence

The correct match is

2. Pityriasis versicolor a)Yellow fluorescence

3. Tinea capitis d)Blue fluorescence

4. Vitiligo b)Milky white florescence


Reference : Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no 4.20 .

questions.text:
Consider the causes of alopecia. Which among the following cause(s) non-scarring alopecia?
A. Alopecia areata
B. Telogen effluvium
C. Androgenic alopecia
D. Frontal fibrosing alopecia
questions.solution:
Non-scarring alopecia can result from conditions such as androgenic alopecia, alopecia areata, and telogen effluvium. Frontal fibrosing alopecia, on the other hand, is a type of primary cicatricial (scarring) alopecia.

Alopecia areata is a chronic, T-cell-mediated inflammatory disease that leads to non-scarring hair loss. It is associated with autoimmune conditions like thyroiditis, lupus erythematosus, vitiligo, and psoriasis. While it predominantly affects the scalp, it can also impact areas such as the beard, eyebrows, and eyelashes. In more severe cases, it can progress to complete scalp hair loss (alopecia totalis) or total body hair loss (alopecia universalis).

Telogen effluvium is another form of non-scarring alopecia characterized by diffuse shedding of normal hair. This occurs due to the premature end of the anagen (growth) phase of the hair cycle and can be acute or chronic.

Acute telogen effluvium typically occurs 2-3 months after a stressful event, such as a high fever, surgery, significant blood loss, or severe malnutrition. Hormonal changes postpartum can also trigger it (telogengravidarum). While it may cause a noticeable reduction in hair density, it does not result in total baldness and usually resolves on its own.

Chronic telogen effluvium refers to the diffuse shedding of telogen-phase hair for more than six months. Common causes include thyroid disorders, iron-deficiency anemia, and malnutrition.


Androgenetic alopecia is a condition characterized by decreased hair fiber production and follicle miniaturization. Dihydrotestosterone (DHT), an androgenic metabolite, plays a key role in its development. It presents in two forms: male-pattern and female-pattern hair loss. Male-pattern hair loss involves frontal hairline recession and thinning at the vertex, while female-pattern hair loss causes diffuse thinning in the mid-frontal scalp, with little to no involvement of the temporal region.


Reference : Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page no 32.24,32.39,32.40,86.17,89.6,89.7,89.14,89.17,89,20,89.24,89.25,89.46 .

questions.text: A patient on Anti PD1 immunotherapy(Nivolumab) comes with pruritus, eczema, and urticarial rashes. Histopathological examination reveals a subepidermal blister. The direct Immunofluorescence of the lesions showed Linear C3 and IgG on the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In the given clinical scenario, a history of using anti-programmed cell death 1 (PD1) targeted immune checkpoint inhibitors, along with histopathological examination showing a subepidermal split, and direct immunofluorescence revealing linear deposits of C3 and IgG at the basement membrane, is suggestive of bullous pemphigoid.
 
  • PD1 inhibitors, such as nivolumab and pembrolizumab, are associated with an increased risk of developing bullous pemphigoid. Histopathology typically shows subepidermal bullae containing eosinophils. Immunofluorescence microscopy confirms the presence of subepidermal splitting and deposits of IgG antibodies and C3 at the dermoepidermal junction.
 
  • Bullous pemphigoid is one of the most common subepidermal immunobullous disorders, predominantly affecting the elderly.
