It is characterized by a subepidermal split, with tissue-bound and serum IgG antibodies targeting BP180 more than BP230 antigens located on hemidesmosomes, which are critical for maintaining skin structure.
 
  • Bullous pemphigoid has associations with psoriasis, including its treatments like phototherapy and psoralen. It is also linked to neurological conditions such as stroke, Parkinson‘s disease, cognitive impairment, and multiple sclerosis, as well as hematological malignancies.



Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 50.1-50.22, 50.52-50.55.

questions.text: A boy is experiencing low mood, decreased energy, and decreased interest in his surroundings. He is not taking food for the past one week. The thought sample says “| lost my head. | am dead. How can | eat?”. What is the delusion seen in this case?
questions.solution:
The type of delusion seen in this patient is a nihilistic delusion.

Nihilism refers to the delusion of the non-existence of self or parts of self. It also includes an attitude of rejection of established values or extreme skepticism regarding moral and value judgments. The patient may believe that they are going to die soon or their organs are rotting. Delusion of nihilism is often seen as a mood-congruent delusion in depression with psychotic symptoms. This patient has three major symptoms of depression — low energy, depressed mood, and lack of interest in the surroundings. However, these symptoms have to be present for a period of at least 14 days to make the diagnosis of major depressive disorder.



Reference : Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page no 9,379-381,451-453 .

questions.text: La belle indifference is seen in:
questions.solution:
La belle indifference, often observed in conversion disorder, refers to a striking lack of concern about symptoms despite their apparent severity. Although not exclusive to conversion disorder, it is frequently associated with it.

Conversion disorder, also known as functional neurological symptom disorder or dissociative disorder, involves the sudden and temporary loss of motor or sensory function without any underlying neurological cause. These symptoms often emerge in response to psychological stress or internal conflict, leading to the hypothesis that such conflicts are “converted” into neurological symptoms. Common presentations include paresis, non-epileptic seizures (NES), blindness, or anesthesia in the limbs. A notable gait disturbance in conversion disorder is astasia-abasia, characterized by a wildly ataxic, staggering gait with irregular trunk movements and erratic arm motions. Despite these dramatic symptoms, the patient may exhibit a nonchalant attitude, as seen with la belle indifference.

In conversion disorder, patients experience a primary gain by keeping internal psychological conflicts out of conscious awareness, which instead manifest as physical symptoms. Additionally, they may achieve secondary gain by being excused from responsibilities and receiving attention or support, which might not have been accessible otherwise.


Reference : Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page no 453-456 .

questions.text: SCOFF protocol is used for assessing:
questions.solution:
The SCOFF questionnaire is a brief screening tool used to identify potential cases of eating disorders, specifically anorexia nervosa and bulimia nervosa.

It consists of five key questions [Abbreviated as SCOFF] that focus on the main characteristics of these conditions:

1. Do you induce vomiting/make yourself Sick because you feel overly full?

2. Do you worry about losing Control over your eating?

3. Have you recently lost more than One stone (approximately 6.35 kg) within three months?

4. Do you see yourself as Fat even though others say you are too thin?

5. Does Food play an overwhelmingly important role in your life?


If a person answers “Yes” to two or more of these questions, it suggests a higher likelihood of anorexia or bulimia.



Reference: Morgan, J F et al. “The SCOFF questionnaire: a new screening tool for eating disorders.” The Western journal of medicine vol. 172,3 (2000): 164-5. doi:10.1136/ewjm.172.3.164. URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC1070794/

questions.text:
Which of the following is used to define dependence?
A. Strong desire to use the drug
B. Priority to use drugs other than any other activity
C. Increased tolerance
D. Persistent use of drugs despite knowing the harmful effects
questions.solution:
According to ICD-11, substance dependence is characterized by the following:
 
  • A strong internal compulsion to use the substance, which the individual finds difficult to control.
  • A higher priority is given to substance use over other activities.
  • Continued substance use despite the knowledge of its harmful effects.
  • The subjective experience of cravings or urges to use the substance.
  • Tolerance develops, requiring larger amounts of the substance to achieve the same effect.
  • Withdrawal symptoms occur upon reducing or stopping substance use.

The diagnosis of dependence can be made if these symptoms persist for at least three months.



Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page no 270.

questions.text: The tactile hallucinations seen in cases of chronic cocaine intoxication is?
questions.solution:
Formication, the sensation of insects crawling under the skin, is a common feature of cocaine abuse and is also known as Magnan‘s symptom or cocaine bugs. Acute stimulant intoxication can manifest with symptoms such as agitation, irritability, aggression, and increased psychomotor activity. Physical examination may reveal tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis. When stimulants like cocaine cause psychotic symptoms, including delusions and hallucinations, it is classified as stimulant-induced psychotic disorder. Paranoid delusions and hallucinations are key features of stimulant-induced psychosis, with tactile hallucinations like formication specifically associated with cocaine use. The occurrence of these symptoms depends on the dose and duration of drug use, meaning not all patients will experience them. Cocaine-induced psychotic disorders are more commonly observed in intravenous users and those who smoke crack, a highly potent and addictive form of cocaine



Reference : Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th Edition, Page no 302-305 .

questions.text: A patient presented with dysuria and pain in the back. His lumbar spine X-ray shows the below finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and X-ray showing diffuse calcification in both kidneys suggest nephrocalcinosis, a condition often associated with hyperparathyroidism. Nephrocalcinosis refers to the deposition of calcium within the kidney parenchyma or tubules and is commonly seen in conditions that cause hypercalcemia, such as hyperparathyroidism.

Clinical Features of Hyperparathyroidism:

Bones:

Pathological fractures

Subperiosteal bone resorption, particularly on the radial aspects of the 2nd and 3rd digits

“Salt and pepper” skull appearance

Osteitisfibrosacystica (Von Recklinghausen‘s disease of bone)


Stones:

Multiple and recurrent renal stones, often associated with nephrocalcinosis


Abdominal Groans:

Colicky abdominal pain, which can be due to pancreatitis


Psychiatric Overtones:

CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms related to elevated PTH levels


Band Keratopathy:

Deposition of calcium in the corneal stroma


Features of Hypercalcemia:

Vomiting

Confusion


ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval



Investigations for Primary Hyperparathyroidism:

Ultrasonography of the Neck:

A safe and commonly used method for locating abnormal parathyroid glands.


Nuclear Medicine Scanning with RadiolabeledSestamibi:

This technique is effective for detecting parathyroid adenomas. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas and is typically cleared from normal thyroid tissue within an hour, but persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue.


Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA):

Useful for evaluating skeletal involvement in primary hyperparathyroidism.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook Of Surgery: The Biological Basis of Modern Surgical Practice, 20th Edition, Page no 927 .

questions.text: Identify the finding in the given ultrasound image.
questions.solution:
The ultrasound examination of the gallbladder reveals a Phrygian cap, which is a normal anatomical variant. This condition involves the fundus of the gallbladder folding onto itself or being separated from the body by a partial or complete septum. True septa are rare; more commonly, the appearance is due to a folding of the gallbladder wall. This variant is typically an incidental finding on CT, MRI, or ultrasound and does not cause any symptoms. The term “Phrygian cap” is derived from the resemblance of the ultrasonographic appearance to the hat worn by the people of ancient Phrygia around 1200 BC.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20st edition, Page no 2423.

questions.text: Banana sign on USG is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The banana sign, observed on ultrasound imaging, is indicative of spina bifida. It is characterized by an abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum and a reduction in the size of the cisterna magna, creating a distinctive appearance. This sign is associated with spina bifida and is also linked to Arnold-Chiari malformation.

Spina bifida is a congenital condition resulting from the incomplete development of the neural tube. Key ultrasound signs associated with spina bifida include the banana sign and the lemon sign.

 

Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition, Page no 193 .

questions.text: Identify the fracture site in the X-ray shown below.
questions.solution:
The X-ray indicates fractures in the 5th and 6th ribs. On the chest X-ray, the ribs appear as light gray strips. The anterior portion of each rib is more oblique, and its medial part is not visible as it ends in costal cartilage. In contrast, the posterior portion of the rib is more horizontal, and the rib‘s attachment to the vertebra is clearly visible.


Reference: Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, 6th Edition, Page no 186 .

choices.text: Useful in young females with dense breast
Differentiates between solid and Cystic lesions in the Breast
Can be used for screening mammographically undetectable clinically non palpable breast mass

questions.text: Which of the following is not an advantage of USG over Mammography?
questions.solution:
Ultrasound (USG) is not suitable for screening breast masses that are clinically non-palpable and not detectable via mammography. Although ultrasound has its benefits in specific situations, mammography remains the primary screening method for detecting breast tumors. It complements physical examinations and can identify masses that cannot be felt. The main goal of mammography is to find small breast tumors. While mammography is usually the first choice for breast cancer screening, ultrasound may be preferred or used alongside mammography in certain cases. The advantages of ultrasound include:

It is preferable for pregnant or lactating women and young women with dense breast tissue (Option B).

It can distinguish between solid and cystic lesions (Option C) and identify abnormal axillary lymph nodes.



Reference: Sutton’s Radiology and Imaging For Medical Students, 7th Edition, Page no 1475 .

questions.text: An MRCP image is shown below. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The MRCP image in question reveals several round filling defects within the common bile duct, suggesting choledocholithiasis. Choledocholithiasis, or stones in the common bile duct, is often asymptomatic but can cause biliary colic or obstructive jaundice. Treatment typically involves ERCP with or without sphincterotomy, followed by laparoscopic cholecystectomy.

MRCP, or Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography, leverages the natural fluid present in the biliary and pancreatic ducts as a contrast agent, eliminating the need for external contrast materials. It is a non-invasive method used to assess the extrahepatic and intrahepatic bile ducts as well as the pancreatic duct. MRCP does not involve any procedures or interventions.

Using T2-weighted MRI, MRCP visualizes slow-flowing or stationary fluids in the ducts, which appear brighter than the surrounding solid tissues. This technique is valuable for diagnosing various conditions of the pancreaticobiliary ductal system, including:

Congenital anomalies of the cystic and hepatic ducts

Post-surgical biliary anatomy

Pancreas divisum

Anomalous pancreaticobiliary junction

Choledocholithiasis

Biliary structures

Chronic pancreatitis

Pancreatic cystic lesions

Trauma to the biliary system


In cases of benign bile duct strictures, MRCP typically shows a smooth, elongated tapering of the duct. In contrast, malignancy-associated strictures are characterized by abrupt shouldering.


Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 20th Edition, page no 1494-1497 .

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who sustained a shoulder injury presented with swelling around the shoulder joint. An X-ray of the shoulder joint is shown below. Which is/are the ligament(s) likely to have been injured?
questions.solution:
• The image indicates that the clavicle has been displaced upwards, creating a gap between the clavicle and the acromion. This suggests damage to both the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.
 
  • The acromioclavicular joint, a synovial plane joint, is formed between the acromial end of the clavicle and the medial margin of the acromion. It is supported by two key ligaments: the acromioclavicular (intrinsic) ligament and the coracoclavicular (extrinsic) ligament. The acromioclavicular ligament has two components: the superior part runs from the upper side of the clavicle‘s lateral end to the adjacent acromion, while the inferior part extends from the lower surface of the clavicle‘s lateral end to the adjoining acromion. This ligament also serves as the attachment site for the intra-articular disc.
 
  • The coracoclavicular ligament, which links the clavicle to the coracoid process of the scapula, is separate from the acromioclavicular joint but crucial for maintaining the alignment between the acromion and the clavicle. This ligament supports the scapula‘s suspension and comprises two parts: the trapezoid and the conoid ligaments.
 
  • Injuries typically occur due to direct trauma to the lateral shoulder or acromion when the arm is adducted, or from falls onto an outstretched hand or elbow.
 
  • To diagnose acromioclavicular joint injuries, standard X-rays are generally sufficient. They can be used to identify injuries by comparing the coracoclavicular interspace distance with that of the unaffected side, and to assess other potential sources of shoulder pain resulting from trauma.



Reference: Gray's Anatomy: The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 41st edition, Page no 787, 803.

choices.text: Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential
Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone
Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male presented with a mushroom-like tumor in the distal femur for the past 2 years. Which of the following features will help the clinician to identify a malignant transformation?
questions.solution:
The X-ray reveals a well-defined exostosis, indicating a diagnosis of osteochondroma. An MRI showing a cartilage cap thickness of 2 cm suggests potential malignant transformation. Although osteochondroma can occasionally evolve into low-grade chondrosarcoma, this transformation is very rare (Option B). Suspicion of malignant transformation should arise in the following scenarios:

1. Growth after skeletal maturity


2. Lucency within the bone


3. Increased scintigraphic activity


4. Cortical destruction


5. Pain after puberty


6. Presence of a soft tissue mass


7. Cartilage cap thickness greater than 2 cm



Osteochondromas are typically benign bone tumors that usually originate from the metaphysis of long bones. The diagnostic hallmark of these lesions is their continuity with the underlying bone, both cortical and medullary (Option C). These tumors are characterized by a bony mass, often with a stalk, resulting from the endochondral ossification of a cartilaginous cap. Most osteochondromas are asymptomatic and are usually discovered incidentally.



Reference: Campbell’s Operative Orthopedics ,14th Edition, Page no 966 .

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with multiple swellings and brown rashes. Her bone scans show increased uptake in the femur, skull, and ribs, and her biochemical parameters are abnormal. She also has a history of hypothyroidism. An X-ray of her femur is provided. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray reveals Shepherd's crook deformity of the femur, indicative of fibrous dysplasia in the proximal femur. This imaging and clinical presentation suggest McCune-Albright syndrome.

McCune-Albright syndrome is characterized by a triad of café-au-lait spots (cutaneous pigmentation), polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, and precocious puberty. It is also linked with various endocrinopathies, such as hyperthyroidism and acromegaly. The condition is associated with mutations in the GNAS1 gene.

Cutaneous pigmentation tends to be more pronounced on the side with severe bone involvement. Fibrous dysplasia, which affects bone development, involves the replacement of bone with fibrous tissue. The condition often presents with progressive limb deformities or fractures through previously asymptomatic lesions, typically in the second decade of life. Symptoms include nonspecific bone pain, tenderness, and swelling in the affected area, with common sites being the proximal femur, tibia, pelvis, and foot.

Radiological findings typically show:

Well-defined, expansile intramedullary lesions

A hazy ground-glass appearance in most cases

Shepherd's crook deformity, characterized by expansion with significant varus deformity in the proximal femur.


Reference: Apley & Solomon’s System Of Orthopedics And Trauma, 10th Edition, Page no 151,170,203 .

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with a history of road traffic accident and a shaft of femur fracture. The patient was stabilized. After 12 hours, he developed sudden onset breathlessness, confusion, and petechial skin rashes over the chest and axilla. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Fat embolism is likely the diagnosis in the given clinical scenario. It occurs when fat globules from the bone marrow enter the bloodstream, typically following a fracture of long bones. The clinical features of fat embolism usually present within 72 hours and include tachycardia, fever, breathlessness, petechiae, confusion, and restlessness. The diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome is guided by Gurd‘s criteria. Although there is no definitive test for fat embolism, diagnostic approaches include urine analysis to detect fat globules and monitoring blood pO2 levels. Management is primarily supportive, with oxygen therapy being a key component.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2091,2093,2094,2095,2121,2122 .

questions.text: The causative agent of this condition is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image showing the classical “slapped cheek” appearance is highly indicative of erythema infectiosum, which is caused by Parvovirus B19. This virus is also linked to pure red cell aplasia.

Clinically, Parvovirus B19 infection can present in several ways:

1. Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease): After infection, the incubation period typically lasts 1-2 weeks. The hallmark feature is a characteristic rash, starting as erythematous facial flushing, commonly referred to as a “slapped cheek” appearance. This rash often spreads quickly or simultaneously to the trunk and proximal limbs as diffuse macular erythema. The child may also develop a fever.


2. Transient Aplastic Crisis: This may occur in individuals with chronic hemolyticanemias, such as sickle cell disease, thalassemia, hereditary spherocytosis, or RBC enzyme deficiencies like pyruvate kinase deficiency. Patients experiencing an aplastic crisis typically present with fever, malaise, pallor, tachycardia, and tachypnea due to severe anemia. A rash may or may not be present.


3. Pure Red Cell Aplasia: The virus primarily uses the erythrocyte P blood group antigen as its receptor. In immunocompromised patients, a persistent Parvovirus B19 infection can cause chronic bone marrow suppression and lead to pure red cell aplasia.


4. Maternal Infection: In pregnant women, Parvovirus B19 infection is associated with nonimmune fetalhydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.


5. Joint Involvement: Approximately 7% of children with erythema infectiosum experience joint symptoms, whereas 80% of adults report joint involvement. Additionally, the virus may cause infection-associated hemophagocytic syndrome in immunocompromised patients.



The diagnosis of erythema infectiosum is typically clinical and does not require further investigation in most cases. However, in immunocompromised patients or for prenatal diagnosis, viral DNA detection through PCR or nucleic acid hybridization may be performed.

The infection is generally self-limiting and resolves without treatment, though IVIG can be administered to immunocompromised children.

 

Reference: Nelson’s Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 1697-1700.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old child with a 3-day history of watery diarrhea and vomiting presented with altered sensorium. Which of the following are differential diagnoses?
A. Severe dehydration
B. HUS
C. Cerebral Venous Thrombosis
D. Hyponatremia
questions.solution:
The differential diagnoses for a child presenting with a history of watery diarrhea and altered sensorium include severe dehydration, cerebral venous thrombosis, and hyponatremia. The absence of dysentery (bloody diarrhea) and the short interval between diarrheal episodes and the onset of symptoms help to exclude Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS). HUS is a form of microangiopathichemolyticanemia, typically seen in children under 5 years of age.

There are two types of HUS:

1. Typical HUS, which usually follows a gastrointestinal infection, most commonly caused by E. Coli. The infection damages the gastric mucosa, leading to endothelial cell injury, promoting platelet activation, and exacerbating the condition.


2. Atypical HUS, which results from deficiencies in certain proteins, such as complement factor H, factor I, or CD46.



Clinical features of HUS include bloody diarrhea, occurring 5-10 days prior to the onset of the syndrome, along with abdominal pain, fatigue, cramping, and vomiting. The most serious complication is renal failure, which may require dialysis or kidney transplantation. Treatment is primarily supportive, and the illness is generally self-limiting.

In a child with altered sensorium or seizures in the context of diarrhea, the differential diagnoses include:

Hypo- or hypernatremia

Hypoglycemia

Encephalitis or meningitis

Febrile seizures

Cerebral or sagittal sinus thrombosis.


 

Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 487,488,572 .

questions.text:
Nada‘‘s Minor Criteria includes:
A. Systolic mumur Grade 3
B. Diastolic murmur
C. Abnormal second heart sound
D. Abnormal BP
questions.solution:
Nada‘s Minor Criteria include an abnormal second heart sound and abnormal blood pressure.

Nada‘s criteria are used to diagnose congenital heart disease in children. A diagnosis of congenital heart disease is indicated by the presence of either one major criterion or two minor criteria.

 

Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 403 .

questions.text:
In which of the following conditions is live vaccination not contraindicated?
A. Digeorge
B. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome
C. Ataxia telangiectasia
D. Complement deficiency
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option (2)D only

Live vaccines are not contraindicated in cases of (D)Complement deficiency. Individuals with complement deficiency have intact T-cell and B-cell immunity and hence, can mount an effective immune response to live vaccines. While these patients are more susceptible to bacterial infections caused by Neisseria/Pneumococcus species due to a malfunction in the complement system, their adaptive immune system remains functional. Therefore, live vaccines are generally safe for them.

However, they are contraindicated in patients with impaired T cell function (i.e. impaired cell mediated immunity) - like DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia Telangiectasia due to the risk of severe or fatal infections. In DiGeorge syndrome, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome, and Ataxia Telangiectasia, the patients‘ T-cell immunity is compromised, making them vulnerable to serious complications from live vaccines. 

Other options

Digeorge Syndrome or CATCH -22 syndrome is caused to 22q11 deletion leading to failure of formation structures from 3/4th pharyngeal pouches(ie thymus and parathyroid gland are not formed). Its characterised by Cardiac anamolies, Abnormal facies, Thymic aplsia,  Cleft palate and Hypocalcemia - hence CATCH-22. Thymic aplasia leads to loss of T-cell maturation/T cell lymphopenia and loss of cell mediated immunity. 

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder caused by mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASp), primarily affecting T lymphocytes. It has a triad of 1. Eczema, 2. Thrombocytopenia and 3. Loss of Cell mediated immunity.

Ataxia telangiectasia is caused by mutations in the ATM gene, which is essential for repairing double-strand DNA breaks. This defect in DNA repair impairs immunoglobulin isotype switching and the formation of antigen receptors, resulting in partial T-cell deficiency. Consequently, live vaccines are contraindicated in these patients.
 


Reference: Essential Pediatrics by O.P Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 179 .

questions.text: The perinatal transmission of infection shows the spectrum of anemia, possibly myocarditis, high output cardiac failure, and ascites. Identify the causative agent.
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of anemia, myocarditis, high-output cardiac failure, and ascites, along with an image showing hydropsfetalis, suggesting a diagnosis of erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease) caused by parvovirus B19. This virus infects fetal erythroid progenitor cells, leading to anemia. The severe anemia can result in high-output cardiac failure and hydropsfetalis. Additionally, the liver, which is involved in erythropoiesis during early fetal life, is affected, contributing to the development of ascites.

Erythema infectiosum typically presents after an incubation period of 4-28 days with a prodrome that includes low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract symptoms. The characteristic rash of erythema infectiosum develops in three stages:

1. **Stage 1**: Erythematous flushing of the face, giving a “slapped cheek” appearance.
2. **Stage 2**: Diffuse macular erythema spreads to the trunk and proximal extremities.
3. **Stage 3**: Central clearing of the macular lesions occurs, resulting in a lacy, reticulated appearance.

The rash is usually more prominent on the extensor surfaces and spares the palms and soles. By the time the rash appears, affected children are typically afebrile and appear well. Importantly, children with erythema infectiosum are generally not infectious at the time of presentation.

Complications of erythema infectiosum include:

- **Arthralgias or arthritis**
- **Transient Aplastic Crisis**: Characterized by a temporary arrest of erythropoiesis and reticulocytopenia, especially in individuals with chronic hemolytic conditions such as sickle cell anemia.
- **Thrombocytopenic purpura**
- **Myocarditis**
- **Papular-purpuric “gloves-and-socks” syndrome**
- **Neurological complications**: Including aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, peripheral neuropathy, and stroke in children with sickle cell disease.
- **Infection-associated hemophagocytic syndrome** in immunocompromised patients
- **Maternal infection**: Associated with non-immune fetalhydrops and intrauterine fetal demise.

There is no evidence to support the use of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) for post-exposure prophylaxis. However, IVIG has been used successfully in some cases to treat B19-related anemia and bone marrow failure in immunocompromised children. There is no specific antiviral therapy available for parvovirus B19 infection.



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 1697-1700 .

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy was presented with a history of chronic cough and foul-smelling stools. His sibling had similar symptoms and passed away a few years ago. A sweat chloride test and CFTR gene studies were conducted. The CFTR gene codes for proteins involved in the transport of:
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described suggests cystic fibrosis, an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7q. The CFTR gene encodes proteins involved in chloride ion transport across epithelial cells. The most common mutation is the F508 deletion.

CFTR encodes ATP-gated chloride channels found in the apical membranes of epithelial cells. These channels regulate ion flow across the epithelial membranes of sweat glands, respiratory airways, pancreatic ducts, and more. A defect in this gene results in high salt concentrations in sweat and thick secretions in the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts. Children with cystic fibrosis are prone to episodes of salt depletion due to excessive salt loss in sweat, leading to hypochloremic alkalosis and increased serum bicarbonate levels.

### Clinical Manifestations and Complications of Cystic Fibrosis:
- **Sinusitis and Nasal Polyps**
- **Respiratory Complications:**
- Accumulation of thick, sticky pulmonary secretions with abnormal mucociliary clearance leads to obstruction of small and medium-sized airways, causing respiratory compromise.
- The condition can be complicated by bronchiectasis and allergic bronchopulmonaryaspergillosis (ABPA).
- **Gastrointestinal Complications:**
- Thick and sticky exocrine secretions block pancreatic ducts, impairing enzyme production and flow.
- Destruction of the exocrine pancreas, fibrotic scarring, cyst formation, and loss of acinar tissue lead to fat malabsorption, steatorrhea, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies.
- Obstruction of intrahepatic bile ducts and parenchymal fibrosis can lead to hepatic insufficiency and focal biliary cirrhosis.
- Adults may develop distal intestinal obstructive syndrome, while neonates can present with meconium ileus.
- **Reproductive Complications:**
- Males often have infertility due to the congenital absence of the vas deferens and obstructive azoospermia.
- Females may experience infertility due to abnormal reproductive tract secretions.

### Diagnostic Criteria:
Cystic fibrosis is diagnosed when both of the following criteria are met:
1. **Clinical Presentation:**
- Symptoms affecting at least one organ system (respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary)
- Positive newborn screening
- Presence of a sibling with cystic fibrosis

2. **Evidence of CFTR Dysfunction:**
- Two positive sweat chloride tests obtained on separate days
- Identification of two CFTR mutations via genetic testing
- An abnormal nasal potential difference measurement

### Management:
Cystic fibrosis management requires a multidisciplinary approach. Treatment options include:
- **Lumacaftor:** An FDA-approved drug that corrects protein misfolding associated with the F508del mutation.
- **Ivacaftor:** A medication that potentiates CFTR channel opening and enhances ion transport.
- **Lung Transplantation:** Considered in cases of end-stage pulmonary failure.


Reference : Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 2282,2283,2285-2288,2292-2295 .

questions.text: Which of the following is a new drug approved by the FDA for the treatment of Rett syndrome?
questions.solution:
Trofinetide is a newly FDA-approved drug for treating Rett syndrome. While the exact mechanism of its therapeutic effects in patients with Rett syndrome remains unclear, trofinetide is a synthetic analog of the amino-terminal tripeptide of insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1). It is designed to address the core symptoms of Rett syndrome by potentially reducing neuroinflammation and supporting synaptic function through the protein fragment glypromate (GPE).

IGF-1 is produced by both major brain cell types—neurons and glia—and is essential for normal brain development and the brain‘s response to injury and disease. Trofinetide has been found to inhibit the production of inflammatory cytokines, reduce the overactivation of microglia and astrocytes, and increase the availability of IGF-1 for binding to IGF-1 receptors.

Indicated specifically for the treatment of Rett syndrome, trofinetide‘s adverse effects can include diarrhea, vomiting, fever, seizures, anxiety, decreased appetite, fatigue, and nasopharyngitis.

 

Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page no 292-293 .

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presented with a history of fever, conjunctival congestion, and erythematous desquamation of the skin as shown in the images below. A 2D echo shows a coronary aneurysm. What is the first line of treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
Kawasaki disease, also known as mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome, is a vasculitis condition of unknown etiology. It often presents with a history of fever, conjunctival congestion, strawberry tongue, and erythematous desquamation of the skin. The primary treatment for Kawasaki disease is intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG).

**Clinical Features:**
Patients typically exhibit a high, spiking fever that is unresponsive to antipyretics, lasting between 5 days to 3-4 weeks. The diagnosis of Kawasaki disease requires the presence of fever and at least four of the five principal clinical criteria, which include:

1. **Bilateral nonexudative conjunctival infection** with limbal sparing.
2. **Erythema of the oral and pharyngeal mucosa**, including strawberry tongue and red, cracked lips.
3. **Edema and erythema of the hands and feet**.
4. Various forms of **rash**, including maculopapular, erythema multiforme, or scarlatiniform.
5. **Nonsuppurative cervical lymphadenopathy**.

**Complications:**
Myocarditis is a common complication during the acute phase of Kawasaki disease, often presenting as tachycardia and reduced ventricular systolic function, with tachycardia being disproportionate to the fever. Coronary artery aneurysms can develop in the 2nd to 3rd week of illness. These aneurysms are typically asymptomatic and are diagnosed via echocardiography, which should be performed at diagnosis and repeated after 1-2 weeks. Large aneurysms pose a risk of death.

**Additional Symptoms:**
Other symptoms may include periungual desquamation, gastrointestinal symptoms (vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea), cough, rhinorrhea, and arthritis. Laboratory findings usually show elevated leukocytes, platelets, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein levels.

**Treatment:**
The first line of treatment involves administering 2g/kg of intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) as an infusion over 10-12 hours, ideally within 10 days of onset. Moderate to high-dose aspirin should also be administered until the patient is afebrile.


Reference : Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 1310-1315 .

questions.text: Which of the following has the least risk of perinatal transmission?
questions.solution:
Rubella has the least risk of perinatal transmission.

Rubella or German measles has an intrauterine transmission that causes serious infection in pregnancy which results in abortions or severe fetal defects if infection occurs in the first trimester. The classical triad of congenital rubella syndrome is deafness, cataract, and congenital heart disease.


Reference : Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd Edition, Page no 1155,1156 .

questions.text: In a baby born with meconium-stained liquor, which of the following are recommended as per Neonatal Resuscitation guidelines?A. Intrapartum suction of nose and mouth before delivery of shoulderB. Intratracheal suction in case of nonvigorous babyC. Gentle suction of nose and mouth in case of vigorous babyD. PPV in case of non vigorous baby after early steps
questions.solution:
In the case of a baby born with meconium-stained amniotic fluid, management depends on the baby‘s condition at birth:

1. **Vigorous Baby:** If the baby is vigorous, meaning they have good breathing and normal muscle tone, gentle suction of the nose and mouth is performed. The baby can then be kept with the mother. Routine tracheal suctioning is not recommended in this scenario.

2. **Non-Vigorous Baby:** If the baby is non-vigorous, meaning they have poor or no breathing and decreased muscle tone, initial resuscitation steps are taken. If the baby does not respond to these steps, positive pressure ventilation (PPV) with a bag and mask is provided.


**Neonatal Resuscitation Guidelines:**

- **Heart Rate <100:** Provide PPV and monitor oxygen saturation (SpO2). Ensure adequate ventilation.
- **Heart Rate <60:** Initiate chest compressions over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions per minute. The recommended rate of ventilation is 30 inflations per minute. The ratio of compressions to ventilations should be 3:1.
- **Heart Rate Still <60:** If the heart rate remains below 60 despite effective compressions and ventilation, administer IV epinephrine.

Assess the baby‘s response to resuscitation based on heart rate and adjust interventions accordingly.


Reference : Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page no 925-927.

questions.text: Which among the following indicates severe COVID?
questions.solution:
• SpO2 < 90% on room air indicates severe COVID.
 
  • According to the clinical guidelines for the management of COVID-19 patients released by the AIIMS/ICMR task force, a respiratory rate of >24/min constitutes moderate COVID, not severe COVID.





Reference: AIIMS/ICMR-COVID-19 National Task Force/ Joint Monitoring Group (Dte.GHS), MoHFW INDIA Clinical Guidance for Management of Adult COVID-19 Patients revised on 14/01/2022. URL: https://covid19dashboard.mohfw.gov.in/pdf/ClinicalGuidanceforManagementofAdultCOVID19Patientsupdatedason05thjan2023.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following are seen in iron deficiency anemia?A. Reduced serum iron levelB. Reduced transferrin saturationC. Increased total iron binding capacityD. Reduced ferritin level
questions.solution:
Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is characterized by reduced serum iron levels, decreased transferrin saturation, increased total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), and lowered ferritin levels.

**Serum Iron Level**: This represents the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin. In IDA, as the body‘s iron stores become depleted, the serum iron level decreases.

**Total Iron-Binding Capacity (TIBC)**: TIBC is an indirect measure of the circulating levels of transferrin, the protein responsible for iron transport. In IDA, there is more free transferrin available (not bound to iron) in the bloodstream, resulting in an increase in TIBC.


The normal range for transferrin saturation is 25-50%. In states of iron deficiency, transferrin saturation is low. A transferrin saturation greater than 50% indicates a significant amount of iron being delivered to tissues, which can lead to tissue iron overload, as seen in conditions like hemochromatosis.

**Serum Ferritin**: This is the most useful laboratory test for assessing iron stores in the body. When iron stores are depleted, serum ferritin levels decrease. Serum ferritin levels below 15 pg/L are indicative of completely absent iron stores.
 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 749-750 .

questions.text: A patient recovered from hepatitis B infection. Which of the following curve represents antibodies seen 4 weeks post-recovery?
questions.solution:
The serological marker identified in the image is the anti-HBs antibody. In typical cases of resolving hepatitis B, HBsAg becomes undetectable 1 to 2 months after the onset of clinical symptoms. Following this, the anti-HBs antibody becomes detectable in the serum.

After infection with the hepatitis B virus (HBV), the first serological marker to increase is HBsAg, which can be detected in the serum within 1 to 12 weeks. It typically becomes undetectable 12 months after the onset of jaundice and rarely persists beyond 6 months. Once HBsAg is no longer detectable, the anti-HBs antibody levels start to rise in the serum and remain detectable indefinitely. The interval between the disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti-HBs antibodies is known as the window period.

HBcAg is found inside the cells and is usually enclosed within an HBsAg coat when present in the serum. Consequently, HBcAg is not typically detectable in the serum of patients with HBV infection, as naked core particles are not present in the bloodstream. However, anti-HBc can be detected in the serum shortly after HBsAg emerges, usually within 1 to 2 weeks. During the window period, anti-HBc may be the only serologic marker that can identify HBV infection.

HBeAg appears shortly after HBsAg and its presence correlates with high levels of viral replication. The presence of anti-HBe is associated with a period of lower infectivity.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2564-2567,2571 table 339-2 .

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reversible dementia?
questions.solution:
Lewy body dementia causes irreversible dementia.

Dementia is an acquired deterioration in cognitive abilities that impairs the successful performance of activities of daily living. The most commonly lost cognitive function is episodic memory, that is, the ability to recall events specific in time and place.

Causes of dementia are: Reversible

• Hypothyroidism

* Thiamine deficiency, vitamin B12 deficiency
* Normal pressure hydrocephalus

• Subdural hematoma

• Brain tumor


• Chronic infection

• Autoimmune encephalopathy


Irreversible

*Alzheimer‘s disease

• Huntington‘s disease

• Lewy body dementia


• Vascular dementia

* Creutzfeld-Jacob disease
* Frontotemporal dementia

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 189-191 .

questions.text: A female presented with excessive daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory for one year. On examination, the BMI was 43 kg/m2 and BP was 170/98 mmHg. ABG was done in awake state and the findings are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?PaO.: 70 mmHgPaCO,: 53 mmHgHCO3: 33 mmHg
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an obese patient experiencing daytime sleepiness and hypercapnia on arterial blood gas (ABG) suggests obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS). OHS arises due to factors such as increased work of breathing, respiratory muscle impairment due to the added load, and a decreased central ventilatory response to hypoxemia and hypercapnia. The diagnosis of OHS requires the following criteria:

- A BMI of ? 30 kg/m2
- A PaCO2 of ? 45 mmHg, indicating daytime alveolar hypoventilation
- Evidence of sleep-disordered breathing, often due to obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) (option A) is diagnosed if the patient exhibits either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances or daytime sleepiness, with 5 or more episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep. Each episode should last at least 10 seconds, leading to a >3% drop in oxygen saturation or brain cortical arousal. OSA is diagnosed using an overnight polysomnogram (PSG), which measures breathing, oxygenation, body position, cardiac rhythm, sleep stages, and snoring intensity. The presence of waking hypoxemia or hypercarbia in a patient with OSA indicates the possibility of underlying cardiopulmonary disease or OHS.

Central sleep apnea (CSA) (option D) is caused by an increased sensitivity to PCO2, resulting in an unstable breathing pattern characterized by periods of hyperventilation alternating with apnea. A prolonged circulation delay between the pulmonary capillaries and carotid chemoreceptors also contributes to CSA, often seen in patients with heart failure. These patients may present with Cheyne-Stokes breathing.

Narcolepsy (option C) presents with difficulty in maintaining wakefulness and disrupted nocturnal sleep. However, unlike sleep apnea, patients with narcolepsy typically feel well-rested upon awakening but become tired throughout the day. A distinguishing feature of narcolepsy is cataplexy—sudden muscle weakness without loss of consciousness, usually triggered by strong emotions.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 209,2203-2206 .

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has the following laboratory reports. Calculate the anion gap in this patient having Na+: 145 mEq/L, K+: 4 mEq/L, Cl-: 90 mEq/L, HCO-: 20 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
The anion gap in this patient is 35 mEq/L.

The anion gap is calculated as Na+ - [Cl(-) + HCO-]. In this patient, the anion gap will be calculated as: 145 — (90 + 20) = 145 – 110 = 35 mEq/L. 
K+ conc is not considered while calculating anion gap
 
  • Anion gap is representative of unmeasured anions which are normally present in the plasma, such as anionic proteins (albumin), phosphate, sulfate, and organic anions.
  • When acid anions such as acetoacetate and lactate accumulate in the extracellular fluid, the anion gap increases, causing a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • A decrease in anion gap can occur due to an increase in abnormal cations (such as lithium, immunoglobulins), reduction in plasma albumin (nephrotic syndrome) or hyperviscosity and hyperlipidemia.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 360.

questions.text: A person comes to the OPD with symptoms of not using his left side and not washing the left side of his body while bathing. On examination, he wasn‘t able to draw the left side of the images. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
• The given presentation suggest hemispatial neglect on the left side, likely due to a contralateral (right) parietal lobe lesion. The right hemisphere of the brain directs attention to the entire extrapersonal space, encompassing both the right and left sides.
  • If there is a lesion in the left hemisphere, there is minimal contralesional neglect because the right hemisphere can compensate for both sides.
  • The left hemisphere directs attention only to the contralateral right hemispace. Thus, a lesion in the right hemisphere can lead to severe contralesional hemineglect, as the left hemisphere does not contain ipsilateral attention functions.
Patients with neglect may be unable to dress or groom the left side of their body and may fail to replicate details on the left side of a drawing. Two bedside tests can be used to evaluate neglect:

1. Simultaneous Bilateral Stimulation: When the examiner provides unilateral or simultaneous bilateral stimulation in the visual, auditory, or tactile modalities, patients have no difficulty detecting unilateral stimuli on either side. However, when presented with bilateral stimuli, patients perceive it as coming only from one side, a phenomenon known as extinction.

2. Visual Target Cancellation: The patient fails to detect targets on one-half of the field during target-detection tasks.


Other features of non-dominant parietal lobe lesions include:

- Constructional apraxia
- Visuo-spatial disorientation
- Dressing apraxia


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 199, 200.

questions.text: Identify the type of ANA staining pattern shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The provided image depicts discrete and large speckles in resting cells, as well as the alignment of these speckles in the chromosome region of dividing cells. This suggests a centromeric pattern of antinuclear antibody (ANA) staining, commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (CREST syndrome).

The main patterns of ANA staining are as follows:

1. Homogenous pattern: Characterized by diffuse staining of the nucleus in resting cells, with staining also present in the chromosome region of dividing cells. This pattern is typically seen with anti-histone and anti-dsDNA antibodies. It is associated with conditions such as chronic autoimmune hepatitis and juvenile idiopathic arthritis. An example of homogenous staining is illustrated in the image below.

2. Fine speckled pattern: Identified by the presence of hundreds of small dots throughout the nucleus. Unlike the homogenous pattern, there is no staining in the chromosome region of dividing cells, as shown in the image below. This pattern is associated with anti-SS-A/Ro and anti-SS-B/La antibodies.


3. Coarse speckled pattern: Similar to the fine speckled pattern but consists of larger dots. There is no staining of the nucleoli or dividing chromosomes. This pattern is commonly seen with anti-Sm and anti-U1 RNP antibodies.

4. Dense fine speckled pattern: Characterized by speckles distributed throughout the nucleoli. Unlike the fine and coarse speckled patterns, these speckles are associated with the chromosomes in dividing cells. This pattern is not typically associated with systemic rheumatic disease

 

Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 222,223 .

questions.text: A chronic cigarette smoker now joined a construction company. His pulmonary function test results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?Initial lung volumes were:FEV1 – 0.9LFVC – 1.9LFEV1/FVC – 0.4After bronchodilation:FEV1 – 1.9LFVC – 3.9LFEV1/FVC – 0.4
questions.solution:
In the provided clinical scenario, the FEV1/FVC ratio is less than 0.7, indicating an obstructive lung disease. After bronchodilator administration, the FEV1 increased from 0.9 L to 1.9 L, an improvement of more than 12%, suggesting reversibility. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is an obstructive pulmonary disease with bronchodilator reversibility.

In obstructive pulmonary diseases, the FEV1/FVC ratio is reduced to less than 0.7, and the FEV1 is also reduced to less than 80% of the predicted value. Reversibility is defined as an increase in FEV1 of at least 12% and an absolute increase of 200 mL, measured at least 15 minutes after administering a ?2-agonist. Examples of obstructive pulmonary diseases include COPD, asthma, and bronchiectasis.

In contrast, restrictive pulmonary diseases present with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio (greater than 0.7) and reductions in both FEV1 and FVC. Examples of restrictive pulmonary diseases include asbestosis, sarcoidosis, and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2131,2132,2154,2182 .

questions.text: Which of the following are true about subclinical myocarditis?A.PalpitationsB. Elevated proBNP, TroponinsC. Regional wall motion abnormalities in 2D echoD. ECG suggestive of myocarditisE.Low LVEF on 2D echo
questions.solution:
A patient is diagnosed with possible subclinical acute myocarditis when there is a typical syndrome but without any cardiac symptoms such as palpitations. Biomarkers of cardiac injury are elevated (statement 2), ECG is abnormal (statement 4), and there is a reduced LV ejection fraction (statement 5) and regional wall motion abnormality on 2D echo (statement 3).

Probable acute myocarditis is diagnosed when the aforementioned criteria are accompanied by cardiac symptoms such as palpitations, shortness of breath, and chest pain. When there are signs of pericarditis along with elevated CK-MB or troponins and regional wall motion abnormalities, the term myopericarditis or perimyocarditis is used.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1959,1960 .

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is an AR murmur likely to be heard?
questions.solution:
Aortic regurgitation (AR) murmurs are most commonly heard during ventricular diastole. In patients with chronic AR, auscultation reveals a high-pitched, decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. In mild AR, the murmur is brief, but as the condition worsens, the murmur lengthens and can eventually become holodiastolic. When AR is caused by primary valvular disease, the murmur is typically louder along the left sternal border. However, if the murmur is more prominent along the right sternal border, it suggests that AR is due to an aneurysmal dilation of the aortic root.

Auscultatory findings in AR are accentuated by maneuvers like handgrip, which increases systemic vascular resistance and left ventricular afterload.

Heart murmurs heard during systole include:
- Aortic and pulmonic stenosis: ejection systolic murmur
- Chronic mitral and tricuspid regurgitation: holosystolic murmur
- Mitral valve prolapse: midsystolic click followed by a late systolic murmur
- Ventricular septal defect: holosystolic murmur

Heart murmurs heard during diastole include:
- Aortic regurgitation: early diastolic, decrescendo murmur
- Mitral stenosis: opening snap followed by a mid-to-late diastolic murmur


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1988 .

questions.text: Identify the given ECG
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows broad QRS tachycardia with changing QRS morphology with every beat. The most likely diagnosis in this case is polymorphic ventricular tachycardia or Torsades de pointes.

The causes of torsades de pointes include congenital long QT syndrome, electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalcemia), certain drugs, cardiac conditions like myocardial infarction and myocarditis, and endocrine disorders like hypothyroidism and pheochromocytoma.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1919,1920,1923,1924 .

choices.text: TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases the ADAMTS protease activity

questions.text: Total plasma exchange is done in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. How does TPE help in the management of TTP?
questions.solution:
Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) is a type of thrombotic microangiopathy that can be either inherited or acquired spontaneously. It is characterized by a deficiency or the presence of antibodies against the enzyme ADAMTS13, which plays a crucial role in cleaving von Willebrand factor (vWF) multimers. When ADAMTS13 is deficient or inhibited, these vWFmultimers are not properly cleaved, leading to increased platelet adhesion and aggregation. This results in the formation of platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits in the microcirculation.

These thrombi cause a range of clinical features known as the classic pentad of TTP:
1. Microangiopathichemolyticanemia (MAHA)
2. Thrombocytopenia
3. Renal failure
4. Neurologic symptoms
5. Fever

The formation of platelet thrombi narrows blood vessels, creating shearing forces that damage red blood cells as they pass through, leading to microangiopathichemolyticanemia. The same thrombi contribute to microvascular occlusion, causing organ damage such as renal failure and neurological symptoms. On a peripheral blood smear, fragmented red blood cells, known as schistocytes or helmet cells, can be seen.

Therapeutic plasma exchange (TPE) is the cornerstone of TTP treatment. TPE helps remove autoantibodies against ADAMTS13, allowing the enzyme to function properly and degrade the vWFmultimers. TPE is continued until the platelet count normalizes and signs of hemolysis have been absent for at least two days. Glucocorticoids are often used as an adjunct therapy to TPE, and the addition of rituximab early in treatment has been shown to reduce the duration of the disease and the risk of relapses.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 907,908 .

questions.text: Identify the neurological test being performed
questions.solution:
The image displays an extensor plantar response, indicating a positive Babinski sign.

Normally, when the sole of the foot is subjected to uncomfortable or painful cutaneous stimulation, the toes exhibit plantar flexion, sometimes accompanied by flexion withdrawal of the limb. However, if there is an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion affecting the leg being tested, an extensor plantar response will occur, which is a positive Babinski sign. The minimum extensor response involves at least the extension of the great toe, often accompanied by fanning of the other toes and contraction of the tensor fascia lata. Additional features that may be seen in UMN lesions include spasticity of the leg, pathologically brisk reflexes, and ankle clonus.

 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 235 .

questions.text:
A female with nephrotic syndrome underwent a renal biopsy. Which of the following statements is not correct?
A. FSGS is not diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy.
B. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy.
C. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma.
D. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement should undergo renal biopsy.
questions.solution:
Patients undergoing a percutaneous kidney biopsy are observed for a 24-hour period (statement 2) in the hospital. If any major complication occurs, it is likely to happen during this period, and thus likely to be identified and treated early. Bleeding and hematoma formation are relatively common complications of kidney biopsy and can present as frank hematuria or dark red clots in the urine (statement 3).

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is a pathological diagnosis, so obtaining a tissue sample from kidney biopsy is necessary (statement 1). On light microscopy, there are focal (affecting only some of the glomeruli) and segmental (affecting only part of the glomerulus) lesions. There is a collapse of capillary loops, an increase in the matrix, and deposition of plasma proteins.

In patients with features of systemic

Amyloidosis (statement 4), rectal or gingival tissues can be biopsied for the confirmation of the diagnosis. Examination of abdominal fat pat aspirates can also be used for confirmation of systemic amyloidosis.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2342 .

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient?
A. Hypokalemia
B. Hypochloremia
C. Metabolic alkalosis
D. Respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with a history of vomiting and diarrhea, now presenting with orthostatic hypotension, indicating dehydration and extracellular fluid volume contraction. This triggers activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).

As aldosterone levels rise, it leads to increased excretion of hydrogen (H?) and potassium (K?) in the distal tubule of the kidneys, resulting in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. The alkalosis is further aggravated by angiotensin II, which stimulates the Na?-H? exchanger in the proximal convoluted tubule, increasing the reabsorption of sodium (Na?) and bicarbonate (HCO??).

Hypochloremia arises from the loss of hydrochloric acid (HCl) due to vomiting and is perpetuated by renal chloride (Cl?) loss, which accompanies increased bicarbonate reabsorption.

In metabolic alkalosis, the body‘s compensatory response is respiratory acidosis, not respiratory alkalosis. This occurs through hypoventilation, which leads to an increase in arterial carbon dioxide (PaCO?) levels.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 365 .

questions.text:
Order in which the following heart sounds are heard from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall?
A. Pulmonary
B. Aortic
C. Mitral
questions.solution:
The order of heart sounds as they are heard on the left chest wall from superior to inferior is as follows:

1. Pulmonary — second intercostal space

2. Aortic — can be auscultated in the neoaortic area or the Erb‘s point, in the third intercostal space


3. Mitral — fifth intercostal space

The following picture shows the areas of auscultation:

1. Aortic area, second right intercostal space: this area is primarily used for auscultation of the aortic valve. The murmurs heard best here are those of aortic stenosis, aortic regurgitation, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

2. Pulmonic area, second left intercostal space: this area is primarily used for the auscultation of the pulmonic valve.


3. Erb‘s point, third left intercostal space: this area lies close to both the semilunar valves.

Pathologies of both aortic and pulmonic valves can be heard at this point. Murmurs in this region are more audible if the patient leans forward.

4. Tricuspid area, fourth left intercostal space: murmurs of tricuspid stenosis and tricuspid regurgitation, and ventricular septal defects are heard in this area.

5. Mitral area, fifth left intercostal space in the midclavicular line: murmurs of mitral stenosis, mitral regurgitation, and mitral valve prolapse are heard here.


Reference: Hutchinson’s Clinical Methods, 24th Edition, Page no 200-202 .

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with skin thickening, muscle weakness, and the peripheries becoming pale on exposure to cold. She is positive for ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibodies. Her creatinine kinase is elevated and muscle biopsy shows perifascicular infiltration. What is the antibody associated with this?
questions.solution:
The patient‘s symptoms and findings suggest overlap syndrome involving diffuse systemic sclerosis and dermatomyositis/polymyositis. The presence of skin thickening, Raynaud‘s phenomenon, and anti-Scl-70 antibodies points towards diffuse systemic sclerosis, while muscle weakness and perifascicular infiltration are indicative of dermatomyositis/polymyositis.

In overlap syndromes with polymyositis/dermatomyositis and systemic sclerosis, anti-PM-Scl antibodies are present in approximately 50% of patients. Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are found in about 20-30% of these patients. Anti-centromere antibodies are typically associated with limited-cutaneous systemic sclerosis, while anti-U3 RNP antibodies (also known as anti-fibrillin antibodies) are linked to both limited and diffuse systemic sclerosis and are associated with a higher risk of pulmonary arterial hypertension, interstitial lung disease, scleroderma renal crisis, and myositis.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2776 .

questions.text: A patient in emergency has the following lab parameters: creatinine 1.5 and BUN 45. The chest x-ray is shown below. In gram staining and culture, only rhinovirus was Isolated. The patient is shifted to ICU. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The chest radiograph is suggestive of pneumonia. Since this patient requires treatment in an ICU setting, the drugs of choice would be ceftriaxone plus azithromycin.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1012-1014.

questions.text: A lady on oral contraceptive pills presented with white discharge per vaginum. It is not associated with itching or foul smell and stains her underwear yellow in color. Examination of the discharge revealed normal lactobacilli and acidic pH. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this scenario, the vaginal discharge is not associated with itching or foul odor, and the presence of normal lactobacilli along with an acidic pH suggests a diagnosis of increased normal vaginal discharge.

Leucorrhea refers to an excessive amount of normal vaginal discharge, which is characterized by the following:

- Persistent vulval moistness or staining of the undergarments (yellowish-brown when dry) or a need to wear a pad.
- The discharge is non-purulent, non-offensive, non-irritating, and does not cause itching (pruritus).

This normal discharge is regulated by endogenous estrogen levels. An increase in estrogen stimulates the secretory activity of the endocervical glands, and the superficial vaginal epithelium becomes rich in glycogen. As a result, normal vaginal secretion is expected to increase in conditions where estrogen levels are elevated, such as:

- Puberty: Elevated estrogen levels lead to increased secretions.
- Menstrual cycle: Secretions peak around ovulation due to a rise in estrogen and increase before menstruation due to pelvic congestion.
- Pregnancy: Increased estrogen and vascularity cause an increase in vaginal secretions.
- Sexual excitement: Bartholin‘s glands produce abundant secretions.

Differential Diagnosis:

- Vaginal candidiasis: Typically presents with itching and a thick, white, "cottage cheese"-like discharge. The absence of itching in this case makes candidiasis less likely.
- Bacterial vaginosis: Characterized by a thin, gray, and foul-smelling discharge. Since this patient‘s discharge does not have a foul smell, bacterial vaginosis is ruled out.
- Chlamydial infection: While chlamydia can cause abnormal vaginal discharge, the discharge is usually not associated with yellow staining of underwear, and many individuals remain asymptomatic.

Therefore, the most probable diagnosis is A. Increased normal vaginal discharge.

 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynaecology, 6th edition, Page no 551-552 .

questions.text: What is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia?
questions.solution:
Puberty menorrhagia is most commonly caused by anovulatory cycles.

Anovulatory cycles lead to:
- Unopposed estrogen stimulation
- Endometrial hyperplasia
- Prolonged and heavy menstrual bleeding

Other potential causes include:

1. Endocrine dysfunction:
- Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
- Hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism

2. Hematological disorders:
- Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)
- Von Willebrand‘s disease
- Leukemia

3. Pelvic tumors:
- Uterine fibroids
- Sarcoma botryoides
- Estrogen-producing ovarian tumors

4. Pregnancy complications:
- Miscarriage (abortion)

Treatment:

1. Initial management:
- Reassurance and psychological support
- Rest and correction of anemia

2. Pharmacological treatment:
- In refractory cases, progestogens such as medroxyprogesterone acetate or norethisterone (5 mg, three times daily) are administered until the bleeding stops. Typically, bleeding is controlled within 3–7 days, and the medication is continued for 21 days. Normal cycles usually resume after 2–3 courses of treatment.

3. Emergency management:
- In cases of severe bleeding, conjugated equine estrogen (20–40 mg IV) can be given every 6–8 hours. Once bleeding is controlled, combined oral contraceptive pills are introduced.

Outcome:
Regular menstrual cycles are expected to establish once the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis matures.

 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynaecology, 7th edition, Page no 43,44 .

questions.text: SRY region is located in:
A 32 year old female presents with grey-white vaginal discharge and on gram stain of the discharge, clue cells are seen. Clue cells are-
questions.solution:
Clue cells are epithelial cells with a fuzzy border or granular cytoplasm caused by small gram-negative bacilli adhering to their surface, which is characteristic of bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection caused by organisms such as *Mobiluncuscurtisii*, *Gardnerellavaginalis*, *Mycoplasma hominis*, and *Haemophilus vaginalis*. It typically presents with a malodorous (fishy smelling) vaginal discharge and minimal vulval irritation.

Amsel‘s Criteria is commonly used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis. A diagnosis is made when 3 out of the following 4 criteria are present:

1. Thin, white, homogenous vaginal discharge
2. Vaginal fluid pH > 4.5
3. Fishy odor of the discharge, especially when 10% KOH is added (positive Whiff test)
4. Presence of clue cells on microscopy

The standard treatment is oral metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days. Alternatively, ampicillin 500 mg or cephalosporin 500 mg twice daily for 7 days can also be effective.

 

Reference: Williams Gynaecology, 4th edition, Page no 56,57 .

questions.text: Choose the incorrectly matched option.
questions.solution:
The incorrectly matched term is "Cystocelecolposuspension." The appropriate surgery for cystocele is anterior colporrhaphy.

### Surgeries for Uterovaginal Prolapse:

1. Anterior Colporrhaphy:
- Performed for cystocele or cystourethrocele.

2. Posterior Colporrhaphy/Colpoperineorrhaphy:
- Done for posterior defects such as rectocele or rectal defects with perineal laxity.

3. Le Forte's Repair:
- Preferred in elderly women with advanced prolapse or those unfit for major surgery.
- Not suitable for women wanting an active sexual life as it creates an adhesive area in the vaginal midline.

4. Abdominal Sling Surgeries:
- Ideal for young women who wish to retain menstrual and reproductive functions.
- These surgeries use tapes as slings to prevent organ descent. Examples include:
1. Abdominal Wall Cervicopexy (Modified by Purandare and Mathre): The sling is attached posteriorly to the cervix near the uterosacral ligaments.
2. Shirodkar's Sling Surgery: The sling fixes the cervix to the lumbosacral fascia.
3. Khanna's Sling Surgery: The sling is fixed to the anterior superior iliac spine, strengthening the Mackenrodt's ligament.

5. Fothergill Surgery (Manchester Operation):
- Combines anterior colporrhaphy with cervical amputation. The Mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in front of the cervix, followed by a colpoperineorrhaphy.
- Suitable for women under 40 who wish to retain reproductive function, though fertility may be reduced.

6. Ward-Mayo Surgery:
- A combination of vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair.
- Performed in women over 40 who do not wish to preserve reproductive function.

7. Moschowitz Surgery:
- Used for enterocele repair by obliterating the pouch of Douglas.

### Management of Vault Prolapse:

- For patients fit for abdominal surgery:
- Transabdominal sacral colpopexy, which suspends the vault to the sacral promontory extraperitoneally. This is ideal for younger women as it avoids coital difficulty, which may occur after vaginal surgeries.

- For patients unfit for abdominal surgery:
- Transvaginal sacrospinous colpopexy, usually performed in obese or elderly women who cannot undergo abdominal surgery.

- Colpocleisis:
- Can be performed if sexual activity is not desired.

 

Reference: DC Dutta's Textbook of Gynaecology, 7th edition, Page no 217 .

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association with HRT?
questions.solution:
### Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) and Colon Cancer Risk

HRT has been found to reduce the risk of colon cancer.

### Indications for Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT):

1. **Therapeutic Uses:**
- Symptomatic women experiencing estrogen deficiency
- Adolescents with gonadal dysgenesis

2. **Preventive Uses:**
- High-risk cases for menopausal complications such as:
- Cardiovascular disease
- Osteoporosis
- Stroke
- Alzheimer‘s disease
- Colonic cancer
- Premature menopause, whether spontaneous or following surgery
- Menopause resulting from radiotherapy or chemotherapy, especially with alkylating agents
- Women requesting HRT for prevention of menopausal complications

### Contraindications for Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT):

- Unexplained abnormal genital bleeding
- Known, suspected, or history of breast cancer
- Known or suspected estrogen-dependent tumors
- Active or previous venous blood clots
- Active or recent (within the last year) arterial blood clots
- Liver dysfunction or gallbladder disease
- Known hypersensitivity to estrogen preparations
- Known or suspected pregnancy
- Uterine fibroids, as HRT may cause the fibroids to enlarge

### Uses of Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT):

1. **Short-term Uses:**
- Management of hot flashes and vasomotor symptoms
- Relief from dyspareunia (painful intercourse) and low libido
- Treatment of urethral syndrome

2. **Long-term Uses:**
- Prevention and treatment of osteoporosis
- Reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease

 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 91-96 .

questions.text: Lady with 28 weeks of gestation presents with fever, acute pain abdomen, and mild leucocytosis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this case, a 28-week pregnant woman presenting with fever, acute abdominal pain, and mild leukocytosis is most likely experiencing red degeneration of a fibroid. Red degeneration, a common complication of fibroids during pregnancy, occurs due to ischemia and subsequent breakdown of the fibroid. Key features of this condition include:

- Low-grade fever
- Tenderness of the uterus on palpation
- Elevated leukocyte count
- Elevated ESR

An ultrasound can confirm the diagnosis. Management typically involves non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and the condition is generally self-limiting.

 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 159-161 .

questions.text: Which of the following drug is not given in endometrosis?
questions.solution:
Estradiol is not used in the treatment of endometriosis as estrogen administration leads to further development of endometriotic lesions.
### Medical Management of Endometriosis

*For Minimal Disease:
- NSAIDs: First-line treatment for pain relief.
- Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCPs): Used if menstrual complaints are present. They inhibit gonadotropin release and reduce menstrual flow.

*For Moderate to Severe Disease:
- Oral Progestogens: Initiate treatment to counteract estrogenic effects on the endometrium, leading to endometrial atrophy.
- GnRH Agonists: The preferred choice for managing severe symptoms.

*Additional Treatment Options:
-Cabergoline: A vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) pathway inhibitor, effective for chronic pain related to endometriosis.

*Mnemonic for Drug Classes Used in Endometriosis Management: GOLD GAP**

- **G**: GnRH Analog (e.g., Leuprolide)
- **O**: Oral Contraceptive Pills
- **L**: Letrozole
- **D**: Danazol
- **G**: Gestrinone
- **A**: Antiprogesterone (e.g., Mifepristone)
- **P**: Progesterone (e.g., Medroxyprogesterone Acetate)

 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 180-184 .

choices.text: Weight loss + Metformin + induction of ovulation with urinary gonadotrophins
Weight loss + Metformin + Induction of Ovulation with clomiphene
Weight loss + folic acid, Try for spontaneous induction, if failed move to induction of ovulation

questions.text: A 23-year-old female with 6 years of infertility, has a BMI of 33 and facial hair. Investigations reveal she has (PCOS) and spills from bilateral tubes. She and her husband are trying to conceive, what would be the best plan of management for this lady?
questions.solution:
.**Clinical Management of Obese PCOS Patients**

In managing obese patients with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS), the primary approach involves:

1. **Weight Loss and Folic Acid Supplementation**: Initiate with weight reduction, as even a modest weight loss (5% of body weight) can help restore ovulatory cycles in some cases. Folic acid is also recommended to prevent neural tube defects before conception.

2. **Spontaneous Ovulation Induction**: After addressing weight loss and folic acid supplementation, attempt spontaneous ovulation induction. This is because weight loss can improve ovulatory function in many cases.


3. **Induction of Ovulation**: If spontaneous induction fails, move to pharmacological induction of ovulation.

**Overview of Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)**

PCOS is a multisystem disorder prevalent among women of reproductive age, involving metabolic and endocrine dysfunctions. Contributing factors include lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemia.

**Clinical Features of PCOS:**
- **Menstrual Abnormalities**: Oligomenorrhea or amenorrhea.
- **Hyperandrogenism**: Symptoms such as hirsutism, acne, and alopecia.
- **Insulin Resistance**: Indicated by acanthosis nigricans.
- **Infertility**: Difficulty in conceiving.

**Diagnosis of PCOS:**

The Rotterdam criteria are used for diagnosis. At least two of the following three components must be present:
1. **Menstrual Abnormalities**: Oligo/amenorrhea, anovulation, infertility.
2. **Hyperandrogenism**: Hirsutism or acne.
3. **Ultrasound Findings**:

- Enlarged ovaries with a volume greater than 10 mL.
- Presence of 12 or more small follicles (2-9 mm in diameter) arranged peripherally.

**Investigations:**

1. **Hormonal Studies**: To assess hormonal imbalances.
2. **Ultrasound**: Confirms the diagnosis of PCOS by showing enlarged ovaries with multiple peripheral follicles and helps rule out other conditions like ovarian tumors or endometrial hyperplasia.
3. **Laparoscopy**: In therapeutic cases, may reveal bilateral enlarged ovarian cysts.

 

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 314-317 .

questions.text: A 38-year-old multi gravida presents with 2 years of infertility and dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea. She has a retroverted uterus and tenderness in the pouch of Douglas. What would be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with dyspareunia and dysmenorrhea, along with a retroverted uterus and tenderness in the pouch of Douglas. These symptoms are suggestive of endometriosis. While laparoscopy is the gold standard for diagnosing endometriosis, it is not typically used for initial diagnosis; a transvaginal ultrasound (TVS) is often the next best step.

Endometriosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial-like tissue in ectopic locations, including:

- Ovaries (which may present as chocolate cysts and cause left or right lower quadrant pain)
- Pouch of Douglas (pain during defecation)
- Uterosacral ligaments (chronic pelvic pain and infertility)
- Appendix (right lower quadrant pain)
- Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) scar
- Umbilicus
- Lungs (cyclical hemoptysis)

These extra-uterine sites are affected by hormonal changes, leading to symptoms specific to their location.

Investigations for endometriosis include:

- Transvaginal ultrasound (TVS), which may reveal a chocolate cyst
- MRI
- Serum CA-125 level, which may be elevated (greater than 35 U/mL)
- Laparoscopy, which is both diagnostic and therapeutic, allowing for the identification of endometriosis sites, biopsy, and surgical removal of deposits.

Treatment options for symptom control include:

- Oral contraceptive pills
- Mirena intrauterine device (IUD)
